response: The natural resources are the most valuable commodity the community has. People come here because of a deep connection to the environment; it touches their souls in some aesthetic way, or they derive great pleasure in recreation directly tied to the water (e.g. boating, fishing, swimming, surfing) or indirectly (birding, photography, painting) or enhanced by the location (biking, hiking, writing). Their livelihood may be directly or indirectly tied to those resources (fishing industry, research). Much of the rest of the economy is focused around catering to those who come for the above reasons: restaurants, health facilities, services, seaside related retail.  If the resources are not proactively protected due to initial costs, it can become prohibitively expensive to undo damage once it has gotten to a point of difficult return. Here is a photo of a Chatham seal from 2010.  I have been visiting it since then and see it a few times a year when I am on the Cape. I did see it this past spring when I was at the pier. It's neck has been tangled in fishing line since before 2010, according to the Marine Mammal folks. I'm hoping it was captured and freed during the recent seal tagging project, but have found no information about it. Fishing line does not have the same impacts as nutrients, but certainly is an example of human impact on the marine environment.

I have noticed significant shoreline erosion. This year I did see algae on one of the ponds; however, I never thought to pay attention before, so I can't say whether that is a change. The Painter's Guild exhibits always have seaside related paintings.  There's a race along a seaside route.

Chatham, Brewster, Yarmouth, Wellfleet, Truro, Sandwich, Provincetown, Orleans,  Harwich, Falmouth, Eastham, Dennis\nOrleans. I body-surfed there with my mom before I was even born (we have photos of my pregnant Mom). I love the restaurants.  I pick up fresh mussels and deck drinks; get advice from garden centers; bring my bikes for repair so I can ride into town later for ice cream on my way to the harbor. Several local artists paint my favorite views. I always buy a book. I like the craft fairs. I'm a member of the library; I check out passes for attractions and borrow movies. I like to browse the thrift stores hit yard sales. I photograph the bay, the ocean, Town Cove and ponds. My son rolled over for the first time in Orleans, and ate his first apple. My spouse and our babies took shelter in the last remaining motel room in town during a rainstorm that nearly wiped out our Brewster tent site. I recall my grandfather with wooden leg and cane had to wade into Arey's Pond to grab the rowboat my toddler brother jumped into as the tide took the boat. My grandfather never told the whole tale.

Eastham has bay side beaches (some with tidal creeks into a marsh); tidal flats; coves; salt marshes; fresh water ponds (kettle ponds); swamps; ocean beaches with inlets to estuaries.  These features are enjoyed by boaters using canoes, kayaks, sail boats, small and large fishing and pleasure boats; surfers, swimmers, freshwater and saltwater fisherman; shellfish harvesters; bird watchers, hikers, sailboarders and kite surfers, painters, shell collectors, and writers.

We called it a draw and retreated (without either of us turning away from the other) back from where we came.

response: At this time if I owned the house in which I stay, yes, However, the house I stay in is not mine. Water and wastewater prices in the northeast have not come close to their actual cost. Infrastructure maintenance is not factored into the cost, which has resulted in crisis situations for many municipalities.  They are faced with building moratoriums and costly upgrades and replacement of their collections systems or treatment systems. It's a hard sell to people who live in water-rich environments such as the northeast, but it is critical to adequately fund these systems. Many municipalities have gone broke over these issues. Many communities are considering merging with others or eliminating townships or village status and becoming absorbed by their counties over wastewater or solid waste disposal costs.

Photographing birds is my current favorite activity on the Cape.. It gets me outside to beautiful quiet places (unless near the surf)  in nature where there is always the possibility of seeing something amazing and unexpected. Although I do not own a professional camera, I do have a zoom lens and a small tripod. As far as bird watchers go, I am a neophyte. Experienced birders are always willing to share information and tips and humor with strangers.  These kinds of encounters can bolster anyone's faith that there can be a human community larger than one's own neighbors or workmates. Last year I was lucky enough to find a hawk soaring in place directly above me in the Coast Guard Beach upper parking lot. It was so windy, the bird did not move a muscle or change location; yet still stayed airborne far overhead.  I was able to zoom in for my personal shot of a lifetime (so far).

Increases in the nutrients change oxygen availability and the habitat for the creatures that live in the water at the base of the food chain. This will impact my ability to eat the high quality seafood I love. It already impacts the livelihood of those who harvest from the sea, which in turn, impacts the local, state, and ultimately the national economy. On another personal note, loss of aquatic life impacts avian life and my ability to pursue bird watching and photographing of aquatic, a hobby that gives me great pleasure.  The cape is a destination for birding. Loss of this attraction will impact the economy as well as alter the life cycle of migratory birds, which impacts all other locations used in the life cycle of those birds. Changes in habitat for aquatic insects will impact the life cycles of amphibians and reptiles, which impacts further up the food chain for mammals.Any location using groundwater as drinking water is at risk when wastewater infiltrates into the potable water source. Lack of recharge of water (by sewer or stormwater collection systems) and/or excessive water demand, can lead to draw down of the drinking water supply source, which, when the user is near the sea, has the potential to cause saline water to be drawn into the water supply. Potable surface water supplies are at risk of chemical and animal waste pollution due to runoff. Excessive demand can lead to draw down of surface water supply with the potential for increased bottom sediment getting into the supply.Water resources are the most valuable resources in this country; the protection of them should be considered to be on the level of a matter of national security.Bottom line for me: no more good seafood; no cranberries; no good recreational fishing; poor birdwatching; no more chance of viewing coyotes, seals, sharks, and whales; no good swimming ponds, closed beaches due to pathogens; murky swimming water due to algae and no more clean water from the tap.

This is an important question.  To be honest, I don't know.  I've worked for more than thirty years to educate and engage my neighbors about issues of water quality, but it is still the same 10% who show up for everything and do all the work, while the rest are uninvolved and seemingly uninterested.  At worst, they flush their children's old sneakers down the toilet; at best, they may consider using a phosphate-free detergent if it is cheaper than their usual brand.  I believe--and my career has borne this out -- that people always act in their perceived self interest.  So the trick is to enlighten and inform peoples' self-interest.

Many current residents of Cape Cod, or their ancestors, originally arrived as immigrants.  Arturo may change his plans as his career matures and decide to bring his family to Cape Cod. The opposite is also true--if visitors desert cape Cod for communities that have clean water, his employer's business will suffer and he may be laid off.  We are all in this together--people of all backgrounds share a common need for clean water.

The Cape Cod National Seashore is unique, and an amazing resource, that many on Cape Cod are not familiar with.  It was established in 1961, and encompasses more than 43,000 acres.  It was envisioned in the late 1950's through an interesting political alliance between Massachusetts Senator (and later President) John Kennedy and California Senator Clair Engle, who fought for a similar National Seashore to be established on the west coast, Point Reyes in California, just north of San Francisco.  Imagine the development pressure that was brought to bear, and resisted, on both coasts.  This is evidence that preservation of a unique national resource can indeed overcome development pressure, and stands as an inspiration for those who believe that Cape Cod can move beyond its political divisions and work together to solve the wastewater crisis.

No\nThe key word here,for me, is "prioritize."  I agree that these "greener"solutions are essential as part of a comprehensive plan, but I fear that they will represent a strategy to sweep the huge regional problem under the rug; saying "we're doing all we can afford."  I believe there are situations where these strategies are simply insufficient to the scope of the problem.  For example, I believe that some densely populated neighborhoods found in the Towns of Barnstable, Yarmouth, and probably others with which I'm less familiar, simply cannot adapt non-invasive, "greener" solutions to avoid the need for larger infrastructure, such as a municipal sewer system.  If we spend too much time arguing over priorities, I fear that in the end, nothing will actually be done.
replies: These types of projects most certainly would have to be appropriately placed and sized.  They can't be used as a cop out. One can't dig out a lot, stick in some plants and say one is "done". They are not hands off projects, even though they may visually appear as such.  They require monitoring and maintenance.

response: First of all, to make this an "either-or" question implies the assumption that caring for our environment and educating our children are competing interests for citizens. Perhaps that's the nature of politics, but I'd like to step back and look at the bigger picture.One reason local funding is constantly squeezed is that each day the Federal Government allocates nearly 2 billion dollars of our tax money to defense and homeland security.  I find this out of balance with my basic values, which encourage me to embody joy rather than fear.  I believe that over the long term, we as citizens would do well to increasingly release our fears and own our responsibility to future generations, who will need both a good education and a healthy planet.So I would engage Frank in a conversation about where all his tax money goes--not just the local picture.

I question whether my town would raise the tax rate rather than reduce town services.  Very few people would support paying more taxes, and cuts in services primarily have their most serious effects on people on the margins--low-income, disabled, minority, elderly or immigrants--many of whom, unfortunately, do not vote or engage the public policy process.  People on the other end of the spectrum can purchase such services without involving the Town.  In terms of my own household finances, there is a point where I simply won't be able to afford to live on Cape Cod anymore, or where the quality of life declines below the cost of living, making it more practical and tempting to live elsewhere.

[[[41.59567088863979, -70.2690859375]]]\nI placed my point on the Oyster Harbors neighborhood of Osterville, where a review of real estate listings identifies ocean view homes for sale for $15 million or more.

First of all,I would thank the local officials for taking an interest.  Noticing and acknowledging the problem is the essential first step.Second,I would invite them to "own" the problem, to see how the policies they set might make the problem better or worse.  Third--assuming they recognize their responsibility and accountability -- I'd ask them how they feel about their role. If public policies have prevented solutions, and if officials recognize this, they may feel sad, or angry, or frustrated.  It's important to tap these feelings, and draw on the energy they embody, to inspire them to take action--for their own sake!Actions:  Research to learn more about the problem.  Better choices about allocation of town budget funds to alleviating the problems.  Long-term commitments.  Be specific:  "We need for you to take leadership and make decisions by  [filli n the date!] to take [fill in the specific action] based on science-based solutions for waste-water in xyz neighborhood.Then, keep in touch with them!  Town officials have a multitude of concerns, and the "squeaky wheel gets the grease."  Remember that you're competing with many other issues, and need to keep wastewater at the top of their radar screen.Finally, when they do something positive, thank them.
replies: Great response!

My first priority would be to become as intentional as I can be with my daily activities that relate to water. I could also use a little less water in my washing machine, and use a phosphate-free detergent.  These steps are like "two-fors," where both my property and the water benefit.

I've discovered that I can't change people's minds! All I can do is set an example! I can't "make people care."  All I can do is care myself, and hope that by caring, and by being joyful, people may want to experience the joy I do, and so experience me as a role model, and care, too.  I am a "declared elder" in a circle of support, and as an elder, I adopt certain practices, among them, not trying to change people, but rather simply opening the door for them to change if they choose.

It seems to me that Lin's future will be affected by three factors:1.  Employment opportunities2.  Recreation opportunities3.  Property ValuesIf the Cape Cod communities are able work together to address wastewater issues region-wide, in the coming years the effort will undoubtedly create many good paying, year-round jobs for environmental and hydrological engineers, designers, craftspeople, technicians, and construction workers.  There may well be a great variety of solutions--and hence, a great variety of jobs--depending on watershed-specific issues, pre-existing infrastructure, community resources (both financial and expertise). If I were Lin, I'd get as much eduction as I could in these emerging industries and technologies.2. Recreation opportunities:  Of course, if the quality of water in the ponds, rivers, and ocean declines, the myriad of recreational opportunities, from shell fishing to kayaking, swimming or just enjoying clean beaches, will correspondingly decline.  On the other hand, if the region decides to address wastewater issues, recreational opportunities will stay plentiful across the Cape,and Lin can look forward to a lifetime of active outdoor recreation, contributing to her physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual health.3.  Property values:  Like many young people, Lin may hope to invest in a home or commercial property of her own.  If watewater is appropriately managed in both residential and commercial areas, she can expect the value of her real estate investments to grow over the course of her lifetime, providing a secure nest egg for eventual retirement, and security for the next generation of her family. On the other had, if nothing is done, over the next generation Cape Cod will become an increasingly undesirable region to settle, build a family and a business, and before long, ambitious young people such as Lin will opt to build their families and careers elsewhere, in a region that invests in its infrastructure.
replies: that's a very comprehensive answer. i learned a lot - thanks.

My favorite outdoor activity is swimming in the warm waters of Nantucket Sound in the summer; and in the colder weather, walking miles along the beautiful, deserted beaches and watching the sea birds soar and hearing the winter waves lap the beach and the rock jetties.

If we do nothing, we will, first of all, be judged as the stupidest generation of Cape Codders that ever lived.  Here we have an unique, fabulously beautiful and valuable (both in monetary and spiritual terms) resource, and, by doing nothing, we will deliberately ruin it.  The fresh water ponds will quickly lose their capacity to support a diversity of fish and native plants, and become overgrown with phragmites and loosestrife.  The tidal river will become a sludge sluiceway, wiping out  shellfish beds that have provided food and recreation for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of years.  The ocean fisheries will collapse, as fish, such as herring, that spawn in the ponds no longer reproduce, and the fish that eat them--cod, tuna, bass, swordfish, etc. will become scarcer, more expensive, and ultimately, disappear from the commercial fisheries.  We will feel ashamed, too late, as our grandchildren ask us, "What was a striped bass?  Was "fishing" fun?  What was it like to paddle a kayak on the swamp?"

Fifty years from now, I would like the Cape waters to look like they did 50 years ago.  We need to start in the home.  Residents as well as visitors need to be educated regarding the water cycle.  Everyone must understand that what they put on their lawn, down their drain, in their toilets, ends up in our waterways.  There are still a scary number of people who believe that everything put down a drain or toilet simply disappears.  They need to understand how in turn this affects local biology.  A year ago, I received a great booklet in the mail concerning water quality.  I believe it was generated by the town, but it was extremely well done.  It employed straight-forward, colorful diagrams that even a child could understand.  A comprehensive, one-page diagram could be left in every hotel room, every rental cottage, inside every menu in a restaurant, possibly even as permanent artwork.  The repetition will make people take notice.  Materials like this are very helpful, although they come at a cost.  Social media is faster and cheaper, and we should be looking at this as a means of mass distribution as well.  Neighborhood initiatives might take place in the form of a townwide challenge, with creative awards to the winners.  Those of us with pond rights or concerns could also form communities and initiatives around the pond; many already exist.  It must begin at the bottom, as I've seen the difficulties of pushing a major initiative like this down from the top - all residents see are dollar signs, without any real knowledge of how the consequences affect them.

Water trickles down.  Water issues will reduce tourism, which will reduce seasonal restaurants, then year-round restaurants.  Many will close as a result. It is unlikely he has developed other skills since the restaurant business is his primary focus.  He will have to find another community in which to work.

All residents, All businesses, The state government, The federal government, Visitors\nEveryone!  Businesses, visitors, and residents all benefit from Cape Cod and should participate in its collective welfare.  The government also has an obligation, as these are universal issues.  It truly affects everyone.  Both state and federal government should contribute far more than they do.  It is very frustrating to witness the special-interest and limited-impact programs the government pours millions of dollars into, when we have such real and urgent issues as this.  It is our money and we should demand it be spent where we need it.

Would attend\nWe live in a highly-connected, technological society, so it seems to make sense to deploy any and all modes of communication available.  This game is a great example.  Periodic newsletters, Facebook pages, LinkedIn groups, email blasts, task forces, are all terrific supplemental vehicles for communicating the message and building consensus...why not utilize it all?

Multiple town involvement would provide the long-term benefit of cost savings, primarily from a maintenance and operational standpoint once the system is in place.  However, there are several soft benefits as well.  Consensus may be tougher with more parties involved, but the momentum of joined forces should be stronger.  The more people that are vested, the less likely it is that the plan will be abandoned or delayed.  There will be a larger capital base with which to fund the project, and a larger area over which to balance out densely versus sparsely populated parcels.

A pleasant bonus of moving to the Cape is that nearly every gathering or party comes complete with a freshly-dug raw bar!  I like to know where my food comes from, and it is relatively easy in this community, as so much of it comes directly from the sea.  Water quality is critical to shellfish; even small amounts of contaminants can spoil a bed.  Fortunately, shellfish can frequently purge themselves of contaminants...something our finfish cannot.

Appropriate or not, we are in.  This is a massive undertaking, and the decision was met with great concern and controversy.  The initial construction has been taking place in the off-season on the main streets of town.  It has been messy and grossly inconvenient, and retail shops within the construction zones suffer the loss of business while they are behind detour signs.  It will be very expensive - I believe the estimated price tag was $660 million, and I am sure that this will prove to be too low.  We will be paying for this in our taxes for 20+ years, and that does not include the $10k hookup each house will likely incur just to get to the street.  This is a forced choice:  no one wants to spend this kind of money nor go through this kind of upheaval.  But the consequences of doing nothing are far worse.

Yes\nI wonder how meaningful this is now...since the ocean shoreline is pretty much fully populated with excessively large homes, the ponds have become the second choice for building up.  It seems that, if there is buildable waterfront, it has already been built up.  So yes, I would support STOPPING development ("Limiting" development suggests the deepest pockets may get a pass), and even reducing current development via buybacks and permanent teardowns.

I knew something about it\nI actually knew a lot more than "something" about it.  Chatham has been discussing water quality issues for a number of years, and we are several years into the construction of a wastewater management system.  This is a big fishing community, and water surrounds us, so water quality and water changes are always hot topics around town.

Stillwater Pond is my neighborhood pond.  I use it as a walking destination, and bring visitors there when we are out walking the neighborhood.  I like to walk up quietly in the early morning and watch the wildlife.  I do not yet have a kayak, but plan to get one and that will be one of my first kayak explorations.
No difference\nI answer "No difference", because to me, it's a matter of importance, not a matter of how difficult or easy it will be.  Some things just must be done, regardless of the challenges.

1 - the Pilgrims only ended up in MA because they ran into trouble in the shoals at Chatham Bar and headed north for Provincetown.  Many of our landmarks and addresses still carry names from that earlier time.2 - we have colder springs and warmer falls than the mainland, due to the prevailing influence of the ocean's temperature.3 - we offer vacationers beach options of a bay, a sound, and the open ocean; each with different water temperatures and wave action.  If that doesn't suffice, we have a huge selection of ponds.4 - Cape Cod Beer.5 - We were intentionally made into an island6 - The Cape Cod Baseball League7 - Home of the first wireless transmission (making it curious that our wireless signals are so bad today!)8 - Woods Hole, epicenter of world-class marine research9 - Longest historic district in the US (Route 6A)10 - Despite numerous "capes" around the world, everyone seems to know exactly what "The Cape" is.

Yes\nI absolutely support these, but not as standalone solutions.  I believe we will only succeed by deploying parallel strategies that provide the greatest synergy.  Clearing shoals and algae/weedy clogs from embayments can assist in moving the water faster and getting better tidal flow.  I would be strongly opposed to mechanical means of doing so, as we run into the same problem as wind technology - the "green" solution is packaged with a myriad of its own detrimental byproducts.  Conservation groups have been effective at securing land for years, and we are fortunate to have this protected land.  In a perfect world, it would be great to see an aggressive buyback/teardown plan where marketed coastal and pondside properties were purchased and permanently removed, the land designated as protected open space.  It would be very difficult to fund such a project, but considering that we are looking at a ~$5B wastewater cost, I'd personally prefer to see coastline, not a massive sewer plant.

Change current development rules to limit growth, Acquire and set aside open space to eliminate nitrogen from future growth, Use different wastewater treatment types for the newly developed areas\nHow is this estimate derived?  Is it based on available land?  Perhaps we should be calculating prospective new homes based on nitrogen loading...I am sure we are way past overbuilt.This is a frustrating topic, because we are literally shoveling against the tide!  As we try to resolve the environmental issues, the commercial initiatives pile up, whether they are new mega-homes, pondfront new construction, or big box stores.  The environment requires capital to cure; the commercial initiatives dangle potential dollars over our collective heads.  The money usually wins.It would be nice to see a moratorium on new construction until a cohesive wastewater policy was in place.  It wouldn't hamper teardowns, additions, and rebuilding, especially if there were incentives provided for rebuilding according to environmental code:  low-flush toilets, low-volume faucets, household water treatment units, xeriscaped yards.  Otherwise, we will never catch up.

Mia and her classmates can begin initiatives that they can personally get involved with, and make a difference.  They also have the leverage of social media, and can reach out beyond their immediate community.  They can serve as environmental police in their own households, monitoring fertilizer usage, water usage, toxic disposal.  They can be advocates for something that has even less of a voice than they do, and approach their town government.  There is tremendous power when children propose solutions.  When they take the initiative to address something their elders neglectfully caused, the tables turn and they become the wise ones.  Combined with our own guilt over leaving them this legacy, we are bound to listen.

The school system becomes less relevant when there are fewer students because working families are forced off Cape - those will be some of the first jobs to go if our waterways decline much more.  It will be difficult to persuade voters to think in terms of the natural priorities.  Healthy Environment = healthy commerce = high property values = stable population = well-funded school systems.  Seems we've already made this mistake in some communities; putting the schools first while the population is in decline.  We need to fix the problems, not patch them.

Chatham enjoys an unusually low tax rate, thanks to the highest value properties in the town.  As in most towns, the highest property values are not in the majority - they contribute the lion's share of the tax dollars, but households with the lower property values benefit most.  In addition, many of the households with the highest property values are seasonal residents, thus draining the fewest resources from the town.  Their contribution far exceeds their return; in contrast, the lowest value properties may receive more than they contribute.  Thus the deterioration of high property values will hurt those on the lower end of the scale most.  They will be required to pay more in taxes - something they are already struggling with - and may prove enough to push some over their own fiscal ledge.  The highest-value property owners, on the other hand, may be less tied to the community and, having the greater leverage, may simply sell and exit the community for more pristine coasts, leaving an enormous burden on the remaining households.

It takes a village.  It takes the entire Cape.  This can't be a partial process, and we need to address it locally, but it can't be truly effective unless the whole Cape participates.  That includes visitors whom we often grant carte blanche in our efforts not to offend.  We need to address the infrastructure, the treatment systems, but we also need to impose penalties where the environment is being abused.  Resident and visitor alike need to respect environment, whether that is wanton dumping of household trash in beach parking lots, pumping chemicals onto lawns, leaving refuse on the beach, or dumping from boats.  It must be a multi-pronged approach:  the infrastructure must be developed by the communities, but individuals must be personally accountable.  I am very much against big government, but this is one area I believe we need better enforcement.

I have witnessed massive changes in the relatively short period of time I've lived here.  Much of it is due to the ongoing breakup of our barrier beach, that protects the mainland shoreline from the open Atlantic.  The sand migrates and creates hazardous shoaling or reconnects to the mainland.  Some of this is good; some east-facing beaches have grow deeper over the past few years, but most have grown very narrow.  I've observed this in other towns as well:  the beaches are not as deep as they used to be, and the outer beach all the way to Provincetown was ravaged this winter.  Soft sand beaches become rocky beaches simply via storm activity.  The influx of Atlantic waters and stronger tidal action has actually improved water quality on some of east-facing beaches, but the Sound side does not seem to be faring as well, especially those at the mouth of estuaries.  The creeks exiting the estuaries have been closed for swimming, and there is more and more algae and seaweed along the beaches and in the water.  Low tide is smelling less like low tide and more like sewerage.

The Blessing of the Fleet each spring is a bittersweet reminder that many Chathamites make their living on the sea, and they are at the sea's mercy every day.  Tourists see the picturesque fishing boats leaving the harbor on idyllic summer days, but they don't see those same boats going out on frigid, blustery January mornings.  The Blessing is a reminder to be thankful every time they make it home safely.  Chatham has the distinction of throwing Cape Cod's grandest annual party, First Night Chatham, entering its 22nd year of welcoming in the new year in a townwide, family-friendly celebration of the arts.  Chatham's Fourth of July Parade bursts Main Street at its seams.  Now that the great white sharks are here to stay, we have embraced them as a community.  We celebrated "Sharks in the Park" this year for the first time, and the town is evolving into the shark research epicenter on Cape.  It is fascinating to observe how the advent of great whites in local waters began as a sensational curiosity that morphed into a promotional tool, and is now turning into a commercial and educational platform that is likely to attract more scientists and jobs to the area.  I think it's a great example of how we might harness our local resources to bring capital into our communities.

Chatham, Brewster, Bourne, Barnstable, Yarmouth, Wellfleet, Truro, Sandwich, Provincetown, Orleans, Mashpee,  Harwich, Falmouth, Eastham, Dennis\nBefore I ever lived here, I had vacationed in Dennis, Falmouth, Sandwich, Woods Hole, Eastham, Truro, and Provincetown.  I had a very difficult time deciding where I would ultimately live, because every community is so beautiful and unique.  It is equally difficult to answer this question!  Falmouth for Woods Hole's traditional seaport and the marine academic environment, Sandwich for its historic downtown and Heritage Gardens, Barnstable for the bustle of Hyannis tempered by the bucolic northside, Dennis for its beautiful bay beaches, Harwich and Brewster for their lovely ponds and bikeways, Orleans for Nauset/North Beach and shopping, Eastham for both its lovely bay and Atlantic beaches, Wellfleet for its charming little village, Truro for its wilderness, Provincetown for the vast Provincelands and funky Commercial Street...what's not to love???

Every Cape community is beautiful and special, and we have in common that water defines us.  Chatham is doubly influenced by our bodies of water because it is surrounded by water on three sides.  Its 66 miles of shoreline ranks highest of all coastal Massachusetts communities.  A fishing village populated by many fin- and shell- fishermen, Chatham's welfare is, to this day, heavily dependent on the sea.  Changes within our waters have drastic impacts on our community:  An overabundance of federally-protected seals has introduced great white sharks into our waters and contaminated fish with parasites.  Random and reckless actions by boaters destroy or compromise entire shellfish beds.  Holes punched through our barrier beach by storms threaten homes on the mainland, and have all but obliterated the historic hunting/fishing camps that have graced our horizon for decades.  While it may be true of the Cape in general, it is certainly true of Chatham that the community cannot exist should our waterways become irreparably damaged.(photo not mine, but didn't appear to be copyright protected...)
Inimitable

response: Yes, but not everyone would.  In a perfect world, I would like to see a true analysis of the efficacy of services we already pay for, and eliminate those that don't significantly affect the common good.  Thus transferring monies already being spent into programs we truly need and can succeed at, such as this.

Composting food and waste, Using nitrogen-free household products, Reducing or eliminating the use of fertilizers on your yard, Installing special landscaping that captures stormwater runoff, Installing special bathroom fixtures, Something else (explain in your comment)\nI've been thinking about water for a long time!  Several years back, I was the CFO of an early-stage water purification company, and I learned a great deal about water - including what a difficult problem it really is to resolve.  One aspect we discussed a lot, and I believe is the ULTIMATE solution, is residential treatment units.  We had a prototype of a unit that would reside in the basement with the other services.  Using distillation and incineration processes, water would be recycled back through the system several times, and the water that ultimately made it to the septic was, in fact, already treated.  Think about how small our problems would become if the water leaving each home was clean!  One of our greatest hurdles?  Something we coined the "ick" factor:  Americans found it extremely distasteful to recycle and reuse their own wastewater, even if it tested clean post-processing.  This was less than 10 years ago.
I don't know\nI have to admit, with no more than two people ever living in this residence, and moderate water usage, I haven't given the septic a lot of thought...
replies: You never think about it until there's that strange odor. . .  It's always a challenge trying to remember exactly where the cap is.  Every few years I dig up the wrong patch of flowers before I fing the lid!\\ No problems yet, fingers crossed.  I am hoping that town hookup will happen before it fails!  I hate to admit, but when I first moved in, I did hit a "large flat rock" when starting a bed...

response: There are no easy answers, and each one has a cost.  She needs to get engaged in her community and find out what her town is planning.  If it is not planning, she should ask why:  any town with large homes on the water is materially contributing to the problem.  If her town is beginning regional sewer hookup, she will need to start planning for the expense of the initial outlay and the increased property taxes.  She may gamble and fund the expense through a refinancing, understanding that it will ultimately protect her town, the waterways, and her property value.  In the interim, she can make changes in her own home - using biodegradable or natural soaps and cleaners within the home, investing in low- or dual-flush toilets, consolidating laundry loads and educating her family and guests on water-saving practices.  In the yard, she could eliminate any lawn and xeriscape the grounds in an effort to avoid fertilizers, pesticides and external watering, and ensure safe products are used in the outdoor shower.  She should investigate whether her bayside neighbors have formed a community taskforce and, if not, start one herself.  No single effort is going to make an appreciable difference - it will be the combined efforts of a community that truly turn the tide.

He can choose not to get involved, but it will eventually impact his business.  Zoning regulations will grow more stringent and he may find the septic requirements of his prospective locations unaffordable and unfeasible.  Financial penalties may be imposed on his existing locations, should compliance requirements change.  His plans for growth will be curtailed.  His failure to cooperate in his community may also reduce his political capital in town, and fellow businesses will be less likely to support his ventures.  The community in general may also choose to vote with their feet, and frequent establishments that demonstrate sound environmental practices.  Unless he recognizes that the Cape is a single entity and all its parts must be equally healthy and engaged to succeed, he will eventually fail.

The  nitrogen issue will have a cascading effect.  This isn't a totally hypothetical situation, as much of this has already transpired.  A community doesn't react until they have hard, visible evidence:  they begin to complain about the odor and algae in local ponds, and start to notice it on the beaches.  Beaches are periodically shut down, having failed water quality testing.  Shellfish beds are contaminated with E. coli and sales are suspended.  Local fishermen start to feel the squeeze of unsaleable shellfish and reduced catch, and their fragile financial health plummets.  Visitors tire of closed beaches, condemned seafood, and unusable ponds, and begin to vacation elsewhere.  Restaurants and hospitality fail and Lin's prospects of a hostess job vanish.  Property values decline as demand decreases, and the wealthiest landowners exit first. A declining tax base provides less capital for water treatment, and the cycle exacerbates.  As economic woes and reduced public services decline, crime creeps in.Lin and her family can get involved locally, and initially research what their town is doing to deal with wastewater and how it is protecting natural resources.  They can join local conservation groups and publicize specific issues.  They can get involved at the regional level and participate in planning.  They can take significant steps in their own home, but unless the community is onboard, nothing done at a single residence will have any impact on the outcome.

My watershed contributes to a coastal bay (embayment)\nI live in part of the Pleasant Bay watershed.  Pleasant Bay has long had water qualities challenges, but the 2007 break in North Beach, our barrier beach, increased tidal volume into the Bay and has greatly improved the water quality therein.  What no one really talks about is the fact that all that nitrogen is still being generated...it's just moving directly into the Atlantic.

I spend a lot of time at Cockle Cove Beach on the Sound side both summertime and wintertime alike.  This beach is near the mouth of an estuary that is surrounded by large homes.  This summer in particular, I have noticed a significant increase in what I believe to be algae, as it is different in composition than the seaweed I generally see on this beach.  There is a profuse amount in the shallows, attached to rocks and free-floating.  The photo below - while not algae - is one I took at this same beach on an outgoing tide several winters ago.  The color is accurate - I snapped this because I had never seen water this color before, and was sure that something was leaching into the water.  This is a very challenged area, and I fear for its future.

I have LOTS of favorite outdoor activities, but the only one I can do year-round is walk the beach.  Walking the beach is most amazing in the dead of winter, because nothing about the beach is dead.  The ocean never rests.  I can walk the same beach three consecutive days, and the shoreline is different every day.  The winter beach is the most beautiful - the power of the surf is showcased and the sky possesses so many colors.  I still consider it a true gift to have an entire coastline to myself and stand in the midst of such magnitude.
replies: I love discovering things that have washed up or become uncovered after a storm.\\ Yes!  It becomes a fascinating blend of history and marine biology, when sea creatures wash up with pieces of dishes, boat parts, etc.  The 2013 winter storms off Coast Guard Beach in Eastham uncovered the trunks of a cedar swamp that was reportedly buried for over 100 years.

response: If we do nothing, construction will continue on Cape Cod.  We will build out every available parcel, and increase demand on the aquifer.  Large industry will continue to solicit the Cape with the lure of more jobs.  We talk a lot about keeping the young people here, and encouraging migration onto the Cape versus off it.  Here's an uncomfortable question:  what exactly happens should the Cape's year-round population markedly increase?  The off-season is likely the only aspect that mitigates the summer nitrogen load into our bodies of water.  More households equate to more septic waste.  How much worse would this problem be if all the households on Cape Cod were occupied year-round? The unfortunate irony is that a declining year-round population - while bad for the economy - would actually be positive for the environment.  We need to find the balance.With or without continued growth, if we do nothing, we will likely see our beaches change in a more pronounced fashion than what we are already experiencing:  weedy, algae-laden ponds and beaches, stench of decay, reduced fish populations and sea animals.  The fishing industry will suffer from reduced and diseased stock. The waterways will become unattractive to visitors, the hospitality industry will feel the price pressure, and tourists will eventually opt to take their commerce elsewhere.  The tourism industry will suffer first, and jobs will diminish.  As jobs disappear, people will migrate off Cape and supporting services on Cape Cod will suffer.  Property values will decline in conjunction with increasing taxes, due to a lower tax base and higher water treatment costs.  The economy will ultimately collapse.The beauty and uniqueness of Cape Cod would vanish.  The magnetic qualities that drew so many of us here in the first place would evaporate and we would be left with the knowledge that we allowed it to happen.

[[[41.689390548040286, -69.93270694421392]]]\nMy favorite beach is North Beach Island, largely because it is pristine and wild, but primarily because it is so emblematic of the fragile, constantly-changing nature of the outer Cape.  Inaccurately depicted on every map, the island separated from North Beach in 1987, and will likely disappear completely within the next year or so.  While it is painful to watch it vanish from our horizon, and to know that it will only exist in photographs and memories, there is some comfort in knowing that this is part of a 150-year-or-so cycle of the beach breaking apart and re-establishing itself.  It is awesome to observe the immense power of the Atlantic so directly, and to acknowledge there is a grander scheme than we can know or control.

I grew up in the Boston suburbs, and my family vacationed every year on the Cape.  We started out in Dennisport in tiny, seasonal cottages, and advanced to beautiful private homes throughout Falmouth and Woods Hole.  My family had a lot of challenges and it was not a pleasant childhood.  But everything was always good when we were on the Cape.  Those were the happiest times of my childhood. I continued vacationing on Cape after I left home, initially in Woods Hole and Falmouth and ultimately the outer Cape.  It has pulled at me since I can remember, and I didn't have peace until I finally made a permanent move here.  It is very special to me.

His restaurant business, and by extension his employees and their families, rely in part on visitors to the Cape as customers. Expansion will depend in part on the strength of the economy. If the environment deteriorates, and people stop coming or move away, his business will suffer. Even though he may not live on the water, like most residents, if your home is on a septic tank it drains into the water someplace.  So he is part of the problem, and has a stake in the solution.

If the quality of the water continues to deteriorate, the economy may suffer. Job prospects may be reduced, especially those that serve visitors. She should make sure she and her parents are well informed about the options for finding a solution.

Maybe make some notes to really make your points.Wait until your parents are taking a breather from their hectic lives.  Do something nice for them - maybe bring them something cold to drink.  Then start a conversation about how you would like Cape Cod to be as nice for your children as it is for you.  Tell them that you are concerned about your future and the future that your children might be forced to live in if adults don't make a difference now.  Ask them if they could help you feel better about your future by participating in finding a solution now.  Then, show them a couple of websites that can show them where the wastewater problem stands today and what they might do about it.  And then tell them what you are willing to do to help them.

This cannot be an "either/or" decision.  We need to find a way to stop the bleeding when it comes to environmental issues, but it cannot be at the expense of the children who will inherit what we don't fix.  It will hurt in the short run, but the only correct answer is to vote "Yes" for long-term improvement in the environment AND "Yes" for adequate school funding.

Obviously, there will be a tipping point.  We can handle a little - but there are additional factors to consider as well.  If the decrease in revenue to my town is significant enough for me to see it in my taxes, then I'm seeing fewer tourists, fewer thriving businesses, and an overall drop in the standard of living in my town.  No matter what way you look at it - not good!

First things first, if she is fertilizing the lawn, stop.  Let the lawn go, it doesn't need to be green.  Next, take a look at what is going down the drain.  Read labels on products you are buying or using.  Look for products without phosphorus.  Begin to convert the lawn to native species.  Try a native meadow instead of a lawn.  Plant a native buffer.  Use a pervious instead of a paved driveway.  Install some rain barrells to reuse roof runoff.  If you're going to wash the car, don't let the soap run off.  Long term, see if the town has a water planning committee.  See what plans are in the works.  Maybe the neighborhood will get a sewer or a cluster system.  If they are talking about treatment, then wait and support the plan.  If you are going to be isolated and remain on your on-site system, think about advanced treatment.

Many great and important things start here...the Nausets and the Pilgrims encountered each other at First Encounter Beach (see picture); modern democracy was born, in a unknown and uncertain land; the sunrise is seen from Race Point before almost all of the rest of America. And, generations ago, my family made Cape Cod the starting point for its place in this great country. Some of us have left, in the diaspora that afflicts all families as children grow and explore and move on. Some of us have stayed, caring for loved ones or simply because we love this place. But whether we come back thousands of miles every year, or take the short drive down from Boston, or never left at all, the Cape is in our blood. It is part of us. A smell lingers in our noses, part salt air, part sand, part pine tree, part fish. And all Cape Cod.

50 years is a long time and by then if we are not recycling fresh water and all the nutrients and minerals it (not just cleaning and dumping it), we will have big problems.  We need to understand that the fresh water is a small and precious fraction of all water and using it once and dumping it into the ocean is irresponsible.  It is particularly bad for an area like the Cape because there are no natural recovery mechanisms before it hits the sea.   Phosphorus is a plentiful element but the concentrated sources of it are being used up at an alarming rate.  It needs to be captured and recycled. The same story on many other elements.  Degraded ponds and estuaries may be the least of our problems if we do not take an enlightened approach to full life cycle management of ALL the resources we use. The human impact upon the planet is not sustainable under the current way of doing business, however, the appropriate use of technology and societal wisdom can change that.   The Cape is a better place than most to show what can be done and how.

It is tempting to say that he should care because it is the right thing to do or because if water quality gets bad enough then his job could disappear, but in reality if he is struggling to get by and doesn't plan to stay around here, then maybe he shouldn't care. A successful communications strategy will engage more and more people, but it will take more effort to reach those struggling to put food on the table (their own or a customers) than those who are sitting in comfortable middle class or better homes.

Depending on the development density (number of structures with a bathroom(s)) central sewers are cost effective,  where as in less densely developed areas satellite or cluster systems are more cost effective.  If a densely developed area lies in more than one town, building a central system requires the towns involved to agree to own and operate a central sysltem jointly.Also improving fresh and ocean/estuary water quality across the Cape requires some form of external coordination among communities and towns to prevent inter-town differences (taxes, water qualtiy) from unfair conditions of cost and benefits.

It depends (explain in your comment)\nMy understanding is that the current Mass regulations for septic systems, Title V, and the Cape sandy, porous soils are a mismatch, while being generally adequate elsewhere in the state.  The soil condition requites a more stringent Title V regulation. The water released by septic units moves too quicky in the leach field soil for biological/physical processes to capture dissolved nitrogen (nitrate nitrogen).  The soils lack silt and clay particles that other wise provide a surface on which biological/physical actions capture the nitrate.  Also the soil lack organic material providing carbon on which the biological activity depends.Continued development is fine, but require septic function with Innovative/Alternative septic technologies both for existing and new installations.

The decision becomes a cost-benefit decision concering the particular pollution control technolog being recommended by professionals.

The combination of the large Cape population and porous sandy soils impacts negatively on fresh and salt water quality without significant individual and public investment in and operation of devices and facilities to reduce the release of nitrogen and phosphorus nutrients into the natural environment.  Success requires steady progress over a generation do to the scale being so large, the plant and animal, living systems impacts being so complex, and budgets being modest considering other dollar needs too. Choosing what to do and demonstrating performance is for the Cape popluation, while asking for the Nation's help is fair.  Not investing risks loss of existing public and private investment, and of the opportunity and pleasure to recreate in the Nation's historic, peninsula, ocean community.     The Cape serves the Cape, the state, and the Nation.

response: Water flows through watersheds into the ocean.  Over half of the watersheds on Cape Cod cross town boundaries.   There are numerous "corrective actions" that can be taken -- some more economical than others -- all dependent on the specific characteristics of the land and water and development in the watershed area.Jason is accustomed to doing strategic planning ofr his growing business.  He will see the benefits of selecting the right solution that is most effective and efficient and economical for the area.  "Fast, corrective action" by the town is appropriate only if it's been validated by watershed planning.

Anything that we eat or drink is going to depend on the quality of the water used for its production.  My favorite product native to the Cape is shellfish:  scallops, first choice; lobster, second choice; mussels, third choice; clams, fourth choice; and oysters, fifth choice.  I have visited the Aquaculture Corporation on Chapin Point and hope that they get all of the resources they need (including a wind turbine to generate their electricity) to maximize healthy shellfish propagation.

Located on the west edge of West Yarmouth, our 40B Mill Pond condo complex now has an excellent RUCK wastewater treatment system that maintains nitrogen levels under 5.   Although the system drains to the southeast, we pay $55,000 a year (approximately half of total  system costs) for testing that meets the requirements of a Zone II Protection Area because the Hyannis drinking water intake is located across the town border southwest of our property.  We might welcome a sewer connection if Barnstable were to extend its system to and across its eastern boundary (east of the airport).   We would need to compare the cost of maintaining our independent system with the cost of connecting to the Barnstable system.  We guess that sewering would be preferable but need more information to make a judgment.

I was born in 1932, the year when my family started renting a cottage for a couple of weeks every summer in Wellfleet.  When I was 6, they bought a small cottage on Patchuisett Island, in Pocasset.  My father spent a lot of his time renovatting it and cutting back the brush in the yard.  They put in a bathroom but still used the pump in the kitchen sink.  I loved rowing and swimming in the bay.  Then they had to sell it during the war, for almost nothing, because we needed the money and couldn't get gas or tires anyway.  Skip to the '70s when my cousin moved to Chatham.  Now and then visits to her turned into month-a-year visits in the late '90s and into  full-time residence in West Yarmouth three years ago.  Every day this summer, I've felt a surge of gratitude to all the influences that got me here.  Love it!

We know protecting Cape Cod's environment is critical to protecting its economic future as it is the attractiveness of this asset that creates the demand. What I think is more important, however, is the more global indication of what we value as a society. In a region lauded for its intellectual prowess, how does the Cape as a community behave when an issue so important as this can't be resolved by smarts, money or political will alone? This is the everlasting lesson that my son will learn when we tell him the stories of what the Cape used to be. We stand at the fork in the road - come together as one community and accomplish something big for the greater good or bicker about boundaries and power while an entire region disintegrates.

I have traveled across the country, through 49 states and Canada, and I have never seen anywhere else a divided, limited-access highway with only a single lane and no ability to pass. So that is one thing I can say is completely unique to Cape Cod. Anyone else can correct me if I am wrong.Cape Cod being a coastal peninsula does not make it unique. There are plenty of these. However, I think the Cape stands alone among these destinations for its historical feel and natural settings, particularly along the north side.What makes Cape Cod unique to its region of Southern Coastal New England is the blue collar, working class identity of the locals. This makes the Cape more akin to coastal Maine than anywhere along I-95 or 195. This goes hand in hand with the lack of any 4-year colleges or a vibrant young population. Thus the age demographics are very high and the income demographics are low for the region. This contributes to political struggles toward progressive change.
Yes\nWhy would you not prioritize the least invasive solution? Sewers cost money too.

Change current development rules to limit growth, Direct growth to areas where treatment could be provided at a lower cost, Acquire and set aside open space to eliminate nitrogen from future growth, Something else, Use different wastewater treatment types for the newly developed areas\nBrewster has already done an excellent job with open space conservation. I think the best option of all is limiting growth entirely. In particular, all future growth should be limited to non-residential. The other steps should only be used as mitigation if growth is absolutely necessary.

Mia should make the point to her parents that "supporting the family" includes "being involved in the community." The problem is that people like her parents, who are young and should be the ones fighting to maintain that which makes them want to raise their kids here, as the ones that are "too busy." And then all the older retirees less likely to take action because of lower incentive are the ones who are involved. So, they disproportionately control the process.

I would absolutely say that the environment is more important than the schools. Which one of those two things brings people here and keeps the economy running? No environmental quality means no economy means really bad schools in the future. It is also selfish to neglect the other species that share our environment to whom we have a responsibility. Hopefully, that all is more important to him than a couple people losing government jobs at the school because of cuts. What lessons are we teaching our children if we aren't good environmental stewards?

Seeing as I live as far from the coast as possible on the Cape, this would affect my taxes more than most. However, I also have deeded private access to a freshwater pond a quarter mile down the street from my home. So, if the ability to use that went away, my home value would also drop likely in a matter similar to the coastal properties. So, it would probably all even out.
[[[41.612678554739965, -70.38152413940429]]]\nTough to pick just one place. I'd say it's somewhere on water Osterville, Chatham, or Provincetown.

Do I really have to explain to people how the economy works here? The Cape'sgeography makes it viable as an economy in one way and one way only: as a seasonal tourist colony. If the environment's natural beauty deteriorates, the economy ceases to exist for their kids and the world becomes a drab and crummy place. This is common sense. If the old people are going to be cheap and selfish because they got what they wanted from the Cape and are going to die soon and want the rest of us to suffer from their poor planning, so be it.

I have only lived on the Cape full-time for three years. I can't say I have noticed any particular changes other than erosion which can happen overnight. I also wasn't paying close attention to the water quality when I was a kid here vacationing, nor do I swim in any of the same places now as I did then.
Brewster has Brewster in Bloom. I don't believe it is connected to the water, though I have never been.

Chatham, Brewster, Bourne, Barnstable, Yarmouth, Wellfleet, Truro, Sandwich, Provincetown, Orleans, Mashpee,  Harwich, Falmouth, Eastham, Dennis\nThere isn't anywhere on the Cape I haven't been. I happen to know Truro particularly well having delivered newspapers to the entire town for awhile and have long admired its idyllic rural appeal. Outer Cape has most spectacular ocean views on Atlantic. I like the town centers of Provincetown, Chatham and Wellfleet in particular for their walkability, water access, and people watching and I also like the historic charm of the entire Route 6A corridor between Sandwich and the Brewster/Orleans line. I am particularly not a fan of the stretch along Route 28 anywhere between Falmouth and West Harwich because the commercial development is kitchy and the traffic management is atrocious. Poor road infrastructure is actually also one of my pet peeves about Brewster, as it is the only town on lower Cape that has no east-west route across town in addition to either 6A or 28. This contributes to it having the worst traffic along Route 6A of anywhere on Cape, especially to the east of Underpass Rd.

Brewster shares the distinction along with Sandwich of being the only town on Cape that fronts only on Cape Cod Bay and not on either the Atlantic Ocean, Nantucket Sound, or Buzzard's Bay. It is also unique in the amount of large freshwater ponds it possesses, namely Long Pond, Seymour Pond, Sheep Pond, Cliff Pond, Upper Mill Pond, and Walker's Pond. I know that the abundance of these ponds in South Brewster is one thing that drew me to that area in particular.
rural, non-commercial, bayside
Yes. As of now, the only expense I have for water each year is for the water itself from the water department. That is easily $300 or less per year. I would gladly pay more.

Composting food and waste, Using nitrogen-free household products, Reducing or eliminating the use of fertilizers on your yard, Installing special landscaping that captures stormwater runoff, Installing special bathroom fixtures, Something else (explain in your comment)\nI have never used any fertilizer in my yard. In fact, my property has basically no grass because it is easier to maintain.I never use any cleaning products that aren't ammonia free and untested on any animals. It's just the right thing to do.All the landscaping on my property is around the areas where stormwater runs off, though there is nothing I can do to keep it from running into the street off the driveway where it pools and sinks into the ground.I will explore options for composting, particularly now that Brewster has gone to pay-as-you-throw. But I don't have much food waste as it is nor do I put anything down the drain or in the toilet. It just goes in the trash.I do have low flow bathroom fixtures. Next time I need to replace a toilet, I will definitely get a composting one.I also make sure I pick up dog poop in a timely fashion in my yard, but when we go on walks, my dog veers off and goes deep in the woods. I'll be more aware now.

I don't know\nI bought my home in July 2011 and have never had my septic pumped or replaced. I do not know the last time the previous owner had it pumped. I have consulted a professional who told me that since I live alone, it is probably not necessary to have it done more than once every five years.

If she isn't a registered voter here and doesn't have any money to contribute, she might take some time to educate her neighbors who might be full-time residents. As a seasonal resident, the changes year to year might be more evident to her. Perhaps in combining their efforts and resources, they might be able to have a greater impact.Then, I would make replacing her own septic system a priority so that her family is doing its part not to contribute more nitrogen to the problem than is necessary.

I would simply tell him that any business owner that doesn't take an active role in civic activities that will have a direct impact, financial or otherwise, on his business and as a result, his family, is just an irresponsible business owner and family man. Civics is not some institution that exists on its own disconnected from the world we live in, it is the world we live in. And particularly at the local level is where everyone's vote matters.Now, his is a difficult business decision. If nothing is done, his business suffers in the long run as tourists stop coming and filling his restaurants. So, if he wants to pass things down to his kids and have them live the same happy life in the same happy place, that will be an issue for him. Then again, if something is done, as a tax paying property owner, it will cost him more in the short run. Perhaps that puts a damper on his immediate expansion ideas. So, he has to determine what is important to him.

I would say her plans needing to change will be far more driven by her personal economic concerns. If she has a job waiting for her and a family to support her like many Cape natives, then great. If not, then the costs of living here combined with the non-existent job market for anyone other than elder health care workers, it is a very difficult place for young people to live.As to the nitrogen issue, yes she needs to understand that if the problem is not addressed, they won't be the "same shores she loved as a child."
Not sure\nIt is very difficult to tell on the map as it appears I am right on the line in South Brewster near Seymour Pond.

Yes, I see algae in pretty much every freshwater pond that I swim in to differing degrees. I know that Elbow Pond in Brewster is a particular concern. Seymour Pond is pretty good as of now. We have to keep the water at our beach regularly raked out to keep the water clear to the bottom though.

Swimming and walking with my dogs. I also love boating with my dogs, but I don't have a boat. I am also an avid RV traveler and camper, but as I live on Cape, I mostly do those activities when I travel off-Cape.

Obviously, something has to be done if we want to maintain what it left of the Cape's natural beauty. The problem is that too many voters are either cheap or short-sighted. I think the three resources you have produced here are extraordinary in their combination of conciseness and information and I think they should be played at every Town Meeting across the Cape. I am concerned for the future of our freshwater ponds since, as I have mentioned, they are my favorite places to swim. I want the water to remain clear.
replies: Thanks Jason!  Please feel free to share the resources you see here.  You can share the videos by clicking on the icon in the upper right corner of the video.

response: [[[41.726834549316195, -70.08841233825683]]]\nThis is the spot where my road runs down to a private beachfront on Seymour Pond shared and maintained by my neighborhood. It is the main reason why I chose the house I did. My dogs and I go swimming here almost daily in the summer. It is the perfect combination of being a very large freshwater body and also being very lightly used. So, though there are many spectacular waterfront views and swimming holes that I enjoy, this one holds particular importance for me for admittedly selfish reasons.

My family started vacationing on the Cape two weeks every summer from when I was very young. In the beginning, my parents tried out different oceanfront destinations to see what they liked. We lived in CT near New York City and I can remember going to the Jersey Shore as well. But they quickly decided that nothing compared to the Lower Cape. We stayed alternately in either West Chatham or South Harwich. What drew me back every year as a kid was the baseball more than anything else and that I could ride my bike pretty much anywhere I wanted to go. That wasn't at all possible where I lived. I have never been much of a beach person to be honest as far as spending a lot of time there in summer, but I love swimming in the less crowded freshwater ponds. Which is why when I decided to move back to the Cape as an adult, I bought a house on Seymour Pond in Brewster.As I had grown up, my family vacationed less and I had lost all contact with the Cape for about a decade, during which time I myself traveled throughout the entire United States. And after all that, I decided that there was still something special from my youth that drew me back to live here. And that is why at age 26, I came back as a full-time resident.

Seeing environmental degradation makes our impact on the land much more apparent. My usual feelings of being blessed to be in an idyllic place, would be mixed with feelings of guilt for the harm we are doing.  While there will likely always be new visitors and residents who see the region as more special than their previous home, those who know the Cape well will think longingly of how it was when they first arrived.
[[[41.80637696117812, -70.00266748046874]]]\nThe perfect mix of sand flats, marsh grass, and interesting creatures, and no crowds.
I first came to the Cape to visit my grandparents, who had vacationed here early in their marriage and decided it was their favorite place.  By the time I was born, they had moved here full time.
I think so

response: If we do nothing, no problems get fixed. The Cape loses it's luster and tourists, our bread and butter, stop coming.
I was born and raised on the Cape! My Mom and Dad moved here from Dartmouth/Stoughton After they were married. Mom was a teacher in the Barnstable School System for a number of years.

I was born on Cape Cod and so was my mom and her family.  I am an avid fisherman and just started working as a first mate on a charter boat out of Falmouth.  I have become increasingly concerned with the freshwater fishing.  It seems like the water temperatures are rising quickly in the summer and the quality and clarity of the water also declines in the some of the bigger ponds and lakes.  At the shore of the ocean, the inlet water quality declines greatly in the summer which I am pretty sure is because of how many houses are so close to the water and how many people come here to vacation.  My mom tells me her dad used to go shellfishing and come home with his limits in a matter of a couple hours. Now it seems almost impossible to find Cotuit oysters and many areas in Waquoit and Mashpee are posted "closed" because of contamination.  I would like to learn more about why these things are happening and what I can do to help.

I was raised in a small farm in the South West of France and  twenty two years ago, I moved to the US as a Post Doc at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, MD,  where I met my husband. We moved to the Cape 11 years ago, in a snow storm !   We are both scientists and work at the Woods Hole Research Center. I work mainly in the tropics, Africa and my husband in boreal ecosystems in Alaska and Russia. The first time I went shopping at the Windfall Market, few days after our arrival, I remember that a customer started to speak with me about the weather while picking up some vegetables... I suddenly felt like home, in France, at our local village farmers market where people go not just to buy food but also to meet friends,  neighbors, and discuss about weather,  politic and the latest gossips... !! I love the cape not just because of its beauty but because of the people, it is  a great community of people that care for each other and also about the world.
[[[41.67016563425471, -70.39260391697735]]]\nI grew up on Shubael's pond...this was where I caught my first fish.

In 50 years, I would like toxic algae blooms in ponds to be something grandparents tell their grandchildren as a history lesson on why we take such good care of our ponds now.  They will have this discussion while eating shellfish harvested from local waters with no issues or warnings regarding the health of the shellfish.  People need to understand that even things that they do themselves in their homes or on their property has an impact, not to mention what they might do while canoeing on a pond or being out in the ocean on a boat.  The actions of individuals matter.
If visitors stop coming because of the condition of the Cape's waters, there will be less restaurants, and he will have a harder time finding work and extra shifts.

All residents, All businesses, The state government, The federal government, Visitors\nClean water is a benefit to everyone, and everyone should have a share (though perhaps not an equal share) in covering the cost.
Would attend\nI will be attending for the watersheds in the town where I work.  Luckily, some of the watersheds are also in the town where I live.

Economies of scale allow multiple towns to address issues at a lower cost.  However, there are a number of things that individual towns (even individual homeowners) can do on their own that could add to whatever regional options are undertaken.

All of the above (love shellfish, cranberries and beer), and all are dependent on water.  Since they all depend in some way on water, the quality of the water has a definite impact on the quality of the product.

The neighborhood I live in has already been discussed as a potential area to be sewered.  I live in a dense development of homes that are mostly on 10,000 square foot lots and many of these homes are within several hundred feet of a pond.  Since the area has dense development and lacks other effective ways to keep phosphorus out of the ponds, it probably at least makes sense to study the area for possible sewering.
Yes\nThere are already limits based on proximity to the water and wetland areas.  Additional limits to further protect the ponds is worth pursuing.

No difference\nThe work needs to be done.  Timing isn't really a factor.

Cape Cod is an island (actually, I think it is several islands now).  I always say that everyone who comes to the Cape is meant to be here -- it isn't the sort of place you stumble on accidentally. You can see the sun set over the water -- an interesting thing for the East Coast.You live over your drinking water.
Yes\nGiven the choice, I would much rather see "greener" solutions than sewering.

She can help her parents remember not to flush medication in the toilet, or down the sink.  She can ask them when was the last time they had their septic system pumped.  She can ask them to use phosphate-free dishwasher detergent.  She can ask them to put the contents of the cat's litter box in the trash instead of in the toilet.  Participating in finding solutions is not always about going to meetings and joining committees.  It begins at home.

Ah...if it were only that easy.  The bottom line is that if no one wants to come here and no one lives here there won't be a need for a school.  The issue of funding for education is right up there with the issue of funding nitrogen remediation.  Neither seems to be getting the money it needs.  I will vote yes and I will encourage everyone I know to do the same, but I am one of those homeowners who could be looking at a major financial hit to fund sewering and other remediation projects where I live (Harwich) and I would be lying if I said I wasn't concerned about it.
An increase in any bill has a negative impact on household finances.

[[[42.058210512359494, -70.19080834960937]]]\nProvincetown is a special place that has always attracted people.  It is an area with limited development potential and a lot of demand, so what's available is valuable.

Why should we be the last generation to be able to love this place, spend time here, and appreciate all that is special about Cape Cod?  There is every reason to do what needs to be done to preserve this place for future generations (and for the other species that live here) and no reason to give up and let pollution overrun the Cape.
Winter storms are causing much greater damage to local beaches, beach parking areas and other waterfront areas.  We are seeing more vegetation growing in ponds, and more algal blooms.

Brewster is all about water.  There are about 80 ponds here and many of them are heavily used, both for recreation and agriculture.  Brewster's beaches attract large numbers of people, some of whom hike a pretty far distance to get to the more isolated stretches of sand. For the longer term, I would go to the Town and see about low/no interest loan programs to upgrade the septic system.

response: I first visited the Cape in 2004 on an anniversary trip. We wanted to get away for a weekend and visit someplace we'd never been before. Arturo's employment is a restaurant which uses and depends on access to clean drinking water and a large functioning title septic system. Arturo lives in an area of town that has sewers. It's part of his utility rent. He does not appreciate that, just up the road, where he works, the restaurant may have to truck in drinking water.  I have been in restaurants on the outer cape where in the bathroom there is a sign stating that the water, from the faucet is for washing hands, not to drink, nitrogen, mercury levels too high. Ultimately this could become too expensive for the restaurant to survive because they are solely responsible for a singular cure. Arturo will be unemployed.And he may learn that ultimately water, like oil, is a finite resource globally and must be conserved. He can bring that awareness back to his home country.

All residents, All businesses, Just those connected to new treatment facilities, The state government, The federal government, Visitors\nWe all contribute to creating the problem. We have to face the fact we need to fix it or we lose everything. However, our population is too small to foot the bill by ourselves. Whatever the solution(s) may be, they must be built to withstand the contribution of the summer population making any solution more expensive. Visitors and the federal and state government have to share a larger portion of the costs because if it becomes solely the burden of year round residents, it will force people to live elsewhere.  Our federal and state taxes have been used to fix Boston Harbor, the Chesapeake bay, etc. it is time we receive similar assistance.

Would attend\nThis is a problem we collectively contribute to, so we should collectively share the responsibility to fix the problem. The more people engage and commit to understand the problem, the greater likelihood of fixing  the problem at a lower cost for everyone.
A coordinated, shared effort and solution can fix the problem, with less infrastructure and therefore less cost.
