No, it would be too expensive in parts of the outer cape. The homes are too far apart. However, there are dense areas in Orleans, Wellfleet town that may benefit from a type of cluster system while at the same time as incorporating natural adaptive management tools.

It depends (explain in your comment)\nEven though there is less, there is some negative impact from homes built on the ponds and ocean within the national seashore. In the "old days" settlers, villages were built away from the water bodies. Small shacks, cabanas were built on the beach for storage and protection.  With sea level rise and an increase of storms and their intensity,  there are many reasons to consider not building on the water. Improve and certify alternative septic systems should be a focus, and if necessary, centralized or cluster systems should be considered for existing homes where severe degradation of water quality exists.
I knew something about it\nI wouldn't call myself an "expert" but I have an understanding and knowledge of the problems.
I have 4 within walking distance, Gull Pond, Herring Pond, Williams pond, Higgins Pond.Kayaking, swimming, walking trails. Beautiful, serene, warm water.

More likely to support\nIf a homeowner does not maintain their house it will decay beyond repair. The Cape is currently on a life support system. If we do nothing and keep kicking this problem to the next generation, the natural balance of our ecosystem will deteriorate beyond resuscitation. We will lose our aquamarine and fishing industries, and the tourism industry that is the mainstay of our economy.

The beauty of it's seashore, ponds, marshes is reflected in a light that surpasses anywhere on earth. Although much has changed, the establishment of the National Seashore and conservation measures taken by the towns, the Cape has been successful in protecting much of it's natural resources, open space and wildlife. It remains a special place where individuals can "let go" of the daily routines and stress, to help put life into perspective. replies: Unfortunately that is untrue. Here are a few facts about Cape Cod Population-Barnstable County residents in poverty  doubled from 5.1% in 2006 to 11.3% in 2010. -Children under 18 years of age in poverty grew remarkably from 3.4% in 2006 to 17.8 % in 2010-Residents age 65 years and over in poverty nearly doubled from 4.4% in 2006 to 8.0% in 2010-In 2011, the mean weekly wage for Barnstable County employed persons was $773 compared with $1,147 for Massachusetts overall.-In 2011 the percentage of Barnstable County residents below 200% of poverty  was nearly one in four residents, an estimated 50,630-less than 200% of poverty indicated income below $29,420 for a family size of two and $44,700 for a  four\\ Technically, all the residents are not rich - it is urban myth.

response: We have frontage on Arey's Pond. We have owned this wonderful property for over 30 years. WE feel we have been good stewards of the land, which was wooded when we purchased it in 1980. We have fished, shell fished, gone swimming and boating from our land and never used a lawn service or applied any fertilizer to our very limited crab grass "lawn". For over a decade have been water samplers for the Estuary Project. We can no longer fish or shell fish. It is disgusting to swim in the summer as you get tangled in the floating algae mats. We gladly pay our rising but reasonable taxes and fruitlessly pour our volunteer efforts into our ; town in hopes that the tyrannical minority that has to date thwarted all efforts to stare wastewater treatment looses their malignant sway with uneducated citizens.

We have 15 individual towns that are very parochial and have a deep distrust of other towns. Anyone in any of the local government positions will confirm this. It is the "Good News / Bad News" secret of the Cape and any efforts to work together.We have a County Government with next to zero power over getting these towns to work together.Finally there are "givers' and "takers" when you look at all regions of the State. the Cape shunts far more dollars into the State than we receive in aid or assistance. We are a huge "giver" area.

The restaurant that Arturo works in may be impacted by the effects of water quality to the environment.  If fewer people are visiting the Cape due to a decline in the environment, that means fewer customers to the restaurant.  Also, if jobs and property values decline due to fewer visitors, this could mean fewer customers and jobs at the restaurant could be cut.  Additionally, his landlord might increase his rent to pass along costs of the wastewater solution.

A coordinated effort could both lower the costs/person or business and could provide a more comprehensive and long-term solution to the issue.  If Jason's town implements a shorter-term, smaller project, long-term costs of doing something will probably be more expensive and/or the Town solution may not complement and region approach (i.e., the short-term solution may just be a waste of money).  Additionally, since many water bodies and resources are shared between towns, it makes sense to coordinate the efforts to ensure that the good work by one town is not being diminished by the lack of effort or a competing effort by a neighboring town.

Ultimately, will doing nothing have a positive or negative impact of taxes in the long run.  Are we just kicking the can down the road and when we finally vote to sewer will we find that the costs are even higher? Yarmouth already has one of the highest tax rates on the Cape. I think the taxes would be a bigger financial burden, of course, but the idea that the tax rate is going up because property values are going down is a big lose-lose situation in my book!

Residents can work off-Cape (with potentially higher salaries), but enjoy life on Cape Cod. I would say that Cape Cod is a unique environment--that it has plant species unique to Cape Cod, and it is part of a migration path for birds and marine life that is very important.  Without taking care of our environment, future generations cannot enjoy and learn about this beautiful place and the plants, wildlife, and marine life that live here.  It is also a special place that draws tourists and creative people (artists, etc.). If we allow the environment to degrade, we will lose an important part of our economy for the future generations.

I have seen some ponds in town that look like they are experiencing eutrophication, with lily pads and other plants. Some years there seems to be less marine life in the marsh, maybe as a result of water quality or storms?  There also seem to be more cattails than before--is that a result of eutrophication?

Yarmouth has a seaside festival in the fall.  Some of the activities are on the water like the canoe/kayak race on Bass River, and the sand sculpture contest at the beach. Some of the vendors have products that are inspired by or use something that comes from the water/beach (e.g., beach glass or shells).

Chatham, Brewster, Bourne, Barnstable, Wellfleet, Truro, Sandwich, Provincetown, Orleans, Mashpee,  Harwich, Falmouth, Eastham, Dennis\nEach town has its own character and assets, and I love something about each town.  I think if I had to choose one town, I would pick Wellfleet for the ocean beaches, great restaurants, and the Drive-In!  (And Mass Audubon/Wellfleet Bay is a gem.)

I feel lucky to be so close to the bay, marshes, and ponds, and I think all of these shape my neighborhood and village community.  The boardwalk at Grey's Beach is a wonderful spot that allows people to get closer to the water and, if they like, to look more closely at what's going on in the marsh (and how it is important for marine life).  We have ponds that are visible from the street (e.g., Dennis Pond) that provide the opportunity to swim, boat and fish, and then others that are tucked away in conservation lands and woods that are a treat to come upon.  All of these water bodies are nice for people to enjoy, and they also subtly give us a sense of our how fragile our environment is.

This reminds me of a situation back in the 60's, when my sister took a field trip to the Museum of Science in Boston.  When she came home, she pleaded with my mother to stop smoking, as she saw what the inside of a smoker's lung looked like, and learned that smoking kills, and could cut many years off her life.  She told my mother that she was afraid that she would not be around to see her graduate form high school or college, or even to get married.  Believe it or not, when a child tells their parents their fears of the effects of a situation, I think the parents listen.  She should formulate her fears and concerns and tell them.  No parent is too busy to listen to their child.  It is out of the mouth of babes that great things happen.
replies: Great comment and great story.\\ Smarter Education- right on!

response: Living in Hyannis, we are blessed with great access to the water for both recreational and commercial users.  Commercially there is Hyannis Inner Harbor.  Recreationally is the harbor (Bismore Park), the outer harbor, Hyannis Yacht Club, Veteran's Beach, Kalmus Beach, and  Sea Street Beach.  In addition there are many creeks and salt marshes: Stewart's Creek, Snow's Creek, Crab Creek and more.  Hyannis Harbor has been polluted since the late 60's.  In season, the water is always only one color: Black.  Off-season, mid winter, it sometimes belongs to the blue/green family.  The outer harbor/Lewis Bay area washed well and appears to be very clean, except you can see the muck along the shore at low tide.  The Creeks (with the exception of Stewart's Creek, which just had a new culvert installed) could all use more flushing.  Their access to the bay is too restricted.  There is still wildlife living here: swans, ducks, comerants, etc.  Not sure how many crabs, etc.  Without the water and our access to it, Hyannis would be like Framingham and Natick.

The challenges to the Plan are most significant because of their cost at a time when a poor economy has made money tight.  I like having a comprehensive plan with input and communication with the public in a variety of ways including local meetings and PlanIt!  When this all works kindly communicate with the Federal government and all the politicians disguised as our representatives.I think there is much value in controlling nitrogen at the septic system level, but the technology is immature.  This is not yet a developed market so you will not see the involvement of major companies.  The start-ups will take the risk to develop the market and, once developed, will be bought out by the big guys.  Research funding is hard to find and very competitive.  Some government funders, especially at the state level have no technical and little business knowledge.  We therefore encounter the comedy of the absurd.

Arturo's goals for his time on Cape Cod are all short term in nature.  Water quality issues have affected us already, but are perceived more as a long term problem.  When Arturo returns to his native country he may be facing environmental problems that are more severe than our own since lower income countries cannot afford wastewater treatment plants nevermind septic systems with nitrogen problems.  He should care because educating himself in the issues allows him to resolving water pollution problems in his home country.  Even so, Arturo has a lot on his plate that is more pressing than environmental education.

All residents, All businesses, The state government, The federal government, Visitors\nThis is a complicated and challenging question.  The enormous cost suggests that we should use all sources available.  The federal and state governments may offer grant money to provide initial capital to get projects started and to help defray costs.  Local government may also issue municipal bonds to raise capital and spread costs over time.  Visitors other than second home owners should not pay directly, but through additional costs passed onto them by businesses.  We don't want to scare them away!  Businesses and residents who contribute to the problem should bear some of the costs.  Those whose nitrogen output is already being handled by wastewater treatment plants or cluster plants should be exempt.  If their current wastewater does not handle  nitrogen then they should pay as well.

Might attend\nI currently live off Cape but if i was still a resident I would likely participate in the public meetings.  Public meeting provide the opportunity for discussion and feedback either on the overall plan or on specific local concerns.

Water quality problems are defined by watersheds, not by town boundaries.  In terms of land size (not importance) Cape Cod is small. Implementation of measures on a town by town basis ignores shared watersheds and ignores cost sharing available in a regional plan.  Moreover a regional plan is assembled with a much better perspective for locating facilities such as wastewater treatment plants than towns whose ability to coordinate the necessary siting information is limited.  A coordinated effort is more likely to produce a positive outcome than one done on a town by town basis.  All Cape Codders, including Jason, will benefit.

Ever since I caught my first fish on Cape Cod Bay seafood has been my favorite native Cape Cod Product.  Water quality is at the heart of the availability and quality of both fish and shellfish on Cape Cod.  For this case nitrogen and other nutrients accumulating in our estuaries directly impact the habitat for fish and shellfish by producing eutrophication and hypoxia at the expense of healthy estuaries which have plentiful eelgrass.
The Sesuit Neck neighborhood in Dennis currently does not have a nitrogen problem.  It is not suitable for sewering and would be far away from any centralized treatment.

It depends (explain in your comment)\nTechnology can provide the answer if it is supported.  Removal and possible reclamation of nitrogen and phosphorous should be doable and economically a potential lowest cost option.  This would allow development.

I was already an expert\nMy awareness of the nitrogen/phosphorous problem began as I researched issues relevant to water technologies around the water/energy nexus.  I now have 5 technologies, 2 are combinations.  The first to be investigated was renewable energy generation using salinity gradient technology.  A base case is seawater/freshwater so I looked for potential pilot/demonstration sites on Cape and in southeastern MA.  To make siting attractive the process can be adapted to help with slowing down eutrophication and hypoxia, but does not solve the problem at the source.As I was adding water purification technologies I found a solution at the septic system level in response to an EPA-CINE Cape Wastewater treatment solicitation.  That led to some encouragement from the EPA to submit a proposal for an EPA-Small Business Innovation Grant.  I use nanotechnology to soup up and trick out some conventional approaches.  This requires using institutional labs.  The grant did not provide adequate funding.

The nearest pond to my historic vacation home on Sesuit Neck is probably Coles Pond on Quivett Neck.  I've never been there.  The second closest is Scargo Lake in Dennis.  I have been there many times for swimming, though not recently.  I did not realize that there were as many as 994 freshwater ponds on Cape.  We are all blessed, and bear the responsibility of ensuring their health for ourselves as well as for generations to come.

More likely to support\nHaving a serious problem that took multiple generations to create be solvable within one generation is encouraging and makes me more likely to support local and regional wastewater planning efforts.  It says that the problem can not only be fixed, but that we and/or our children will see the benefits.

Cape Cod has a sole source aquifer for drinking water.  Its protection is vital for residents and visitors alike.  If it is ever impaired building desalination plants would become necessary.  Cape Cod has an unusually high number of embayments for a coastal peninsula its size.  Accumulation of nitrogen in these embayments and the environmental degradation of them has been a problem for decades and must be solved.  Waquoit Bay may be the most studied embayment in the world.  Adding to environmental stress on the peninsula are the huge changes in population that happen every year as tourists flood the Cape during the summer, bringing with them step changes in nitrogen loading that are typically an order of magnitude or more than off-season loading.

Not sure\nA lot depends upon how effective these "greener solutions" would be.  One of the principal problems with problem embayments is poor tidal flushing.  Will these adjustments dramatically improve flushing in Waquoit Bay as an example?  I think not, but am open to the discussion.  Buying land for open space would help, but it sure is expensive.  I think there are better solutions not on your list.

Something else\nThe problem here is nitrogen, not septic systems.  Nitrogen reduction in septic system effluent with the ability to reuse the nitrogen would be an ideal solution.  Sounds simple, but it is technically challenging.  I am developing a process to do this, but it needs technology development in the laboratory, proof of concept testing, and additional testing to qualify for commercial use.  Funding sources are few and very competitive.  I am developing other water based technologies that need time and attention and compete for my time with nitrogen reduction.

Although Mia's parents may be too busy to become involved with the community to confront the Cape's wastewater problem, they surely do find time for their daughter and can learn from her.  The introduction to the question stated that Mia's interest and that of other children her age resulted from an exposure to the problem in school.  A school project could be suggested by Mia so that she and her friends could deepen their understanding of the problem and challenge them to think through what options exist now and conceptually what other options should be explored.  Although this may be advanced for the kids, they are smart, resourceful, and may think out of the adult defined box.  When Mia asks questions of her parents she is bound to turn into the teacher with her parents as the students.

I would advise Frank to become more educated on the issues and more involved with his community. What we do today affects what generations will be able to do.  Cape Cod's environment is very sensitive and vital to our quality of life, tourism, and to the welfare of all its residents and visitors.  Many people would condemn a pollution source when that source is a business.  The nitrogen problem is different; them is us.  If we don't fix our problem it gets much worse over time hurting anybody and everybody.  People will leave the Cape because the visitors will no longer want to come here.  There is another nightmare scenario: if we don't fix it someone else, say a regulatory body with the power of the Federal Government will, and we probably won't like the solution.

My favorite outdoor activity has been sailing.  After learning to sail at the Dennis Yacht Club I have sailed both for recreation and competitively. If we do nothing Cape Cod quality of life will decline, affecting both natural and commercial environments.  We have already seen declines in fishing stock and other marine life. When I was 2 my parents bought a lot of land on Sesuit Neck from Mr. Stone for $200.  Being 2 I don't remember the experience.  Several years later we built our cottage that consisted of a pre-fabricated ranch style house and began spending our summers on the Cape.  Those were the days of one car families, awful TV reception, and a gorgeous beach a few minutes walk away.  I explored the marina when the largest building was the size of a shack.  When I was 10 I received sailing lessons at the Dennis Yacht Club and so began my lifelong love of sailing.  I remember my parents going to the theater at the Cape Playhouse and bringing back their playbills.  This was rather exotic for a kid and made an impression.  As an adult I attended performances.  When I lived on Cape I volunteered as an usher.  Whenever I can, on or off season, I go to my favorite Cape beach.  I won't tell you where it is or where to park, but if you look across the harbor you will find Sesuit Neck.

There are many fascinating aspects of Cape Cod, but there are a few in particular that speak to me:- The tidal flats of Cape Cod bay. When the tide recedes to a distance of over a mile, one can enjoy the wonders of walking where the ocean used to be. - The abundant and diverse migrating birds that stop by the cape and Islands during their migratory routes.- The many kettle ponds that are on the cape. These were formed by glacial deposits and the water in them is constantly replaced and filtered through the water table. How cool! - The shifting coast line. The sands of time always moving. Depositing here, taking away there. A beautiful dance that will continue to shape the outline of Cape Cod. - The fertile Arts community. Music, art, craftsman, theater, and the many other forms of expression, flourish on Cape Cod. These are just some of the countless things that make Cape Cod such a special place!

I think there needs to be some sort of a leader to coordinate the efforts. I think a regional solution is the way to go. There needs to be an investigation of all the costs involved and how we can contribute without driving homeowners into bankruptcy. One thing I never heaer about is the whole title five law. If I sell my house, which does not have a septic system that meets current title five standards, I have to pay for a replacement system or negotiate a lower sale price to meet the replacement cost. The problem with this is that a title five system is designed for bacteriological control and really doesn't do much for nitrogen removal. My particular lot is such that replacing my system with a title five system would cost thousands more than the average lot. I'm guessing 25 to 30 thousand dollars, I never got an estimate. So, if I spent that much money, I would do nothing to reduce nitrogen loading to my embayment. Wouldn't it be a great planning tool to know how much per lot a sewer system would cost and allow those of us in my situation to choose an alternative that would actually help? How much money would the total be for all of the households in my situation be that could be put towards an effective solution? Some, please do the math!!!

I can see how tough it is for someone in this situation to get involved. He doesn't have a long term commitment to the area. Hopefully, Arturo will be able to get involved and develop a love for the area to the point that he would like to stay here permanently. Yet, high costs involved in solving our eutrophication problem are likely to send many people like Arturo packing, looking for places to live where the cost of living is lower.

All residents, All businesses, The state government, The federal government, Visitors\nI really think some one should come up with the following answer: All property sales now need to include a title five septic system upgrade. While title five is the current standard, it does NOTHING to reduce the nitrogen loading to the embayments! So, my challenge is to figure out how many properties do not meet title five standards and how much would it cost for all of them to do so, which would be a large number, I bet. Then factor in how much these property owners could contribute to a sewer system that would reduce nitrogen loading to embayments. That would be the best source of funding to make something useful actually happen1

Well, obviously, since this is a water quality theme, the health of our drinking water system, which is a sole-source aquifer, is most important to our successful habitation here. I also think there are fantastic opportunities for other cultural scenery to enjoy.Most important to me is the airport at Marstons Mills, which I bet many do not know is named CAPE COD AIRPORT, even though it is a small grass-strip field. Orleans Pond Coalition hosts their annual Celebrate Our Waters Festival every year in September. It is a mammoth undertaking to coordinate over 50 free activities like sailing, kayaking, tours of bogs, water treatment plants, nature walks, shellfish grants, herring runs, and paddle boarding clinics for anyone who is interested. It is a weekend to learn, experience and understand our relationship to the natural water resources, fresh and salt, in our region. Everything is free and open to the public. Thsi year, the Orleans Chamber is adding a film festival based on paddling to kick off the celebration and stewardship of Orleans' water.

Lots of choices here:Consult with a firm like SafeHarbor in Truro or Wilkinson Ecological Design and see if there are ways to reverse any deterioration of beach along Betsy's beach.Work with neighbors, to take action that protects the shoreline beyond an individual property line.Look at run off and plantings along your property line to see if erosion is an issue from the property to the shoreConsider a conversation with the Town and work with their Conservation office to see where they are with water quality protectionEducate yourself about best practices with fertilizer, composting, pesticides, medications and home products to keep as many chemicals out of the ground water as possible.Think about donating the property to a land trust and buying something smaller, if the costs are too high to maintain.

Jason can make a big impact with his personal choices. He can go to Town Meeting. As we saw in Orleans, 6 votes can change the direction for a whole community.Jason can also be sure to vote for the leadership who will tackle the issues, when he is not in meetings or at the statehouse.Jason can use his power as a business owner to have his business at the forefront of sustainable practices, getting green certification through the local economic development council, joining Cape Light Compact and having an energy audit, talking with Cotuit Solar or MyGeneration and installing solar panels on his businesses or make arrangements with Nauset Disposal to recycle and reduce the solid waste from his business.Jason can walk the walk without going to a whole lot of meetings.

What future? Wastewater is a challenge that goes hand in glove with how we plan for human resources as well. This is a challenge for each generation in every part of the world. As we move from having one generation in charge to the next, the challenges change and the question is about the collective value system that guides our navigation through these challenges. If we are only looking out for our own backyards, Lin has no future on Cape Cod. The answer is us. We are back to the President Kennedy challenge to ask what we can do our the Cape.

At some point, it will be the only thing left.

One of the biggest problems the 15 towns of Cape Cape has had for over 328 years, since the creation of Barnstable County, is to think that each town needs to come up with its own solution.  This type of thinking is what has held the Cape back for way too many years. Over the past twenty-three years that we have lived on the Cape, I have been part of nearly every effort to develop an understanding that we must all work together as a region. There are very few town specific problems and needs that have a town specific solutions.  With a background in not just government but also regional transportation and environmental planning, I know that most problems and needs must be solved by a process that is coordinated, comprehensive and collaborative to develop the solutions for these community identified problems and needs.

Needless to say, being from New Orleans originally, Cape Cod oysters are my favorite local product and they have become a favorite far and wide since they are the menus of many restaurants all around the country.  Keep in mind that railroads come to the Cape as a way to transport many Cape products to markets all over the US. The Cape's seafood, whether fish or shellfish were important of the Cape economy during much of the late 19th and early 20th Century.  If you haven't read Mark Kurlansky's book, "The Big Oyster", its a must read.  Keep in mind the reason the Dutch settled New York was its harbor was a major oyster bed and once they dumped everything you can imagine into their ponds, lakes and waterway, thus destroying their oyster beds, those east of NYC all the way to the Cape became the source not only for New Yorkers but the rest of the country.

I was already an expert\nThese issue have been on my radar since we moved to the Cape. Another issue we need to deal with is high acid levels in Cape water.  Within the first five years of moving into our house in 1990, we had the hot water heater in the basement have its bottom rot out making quite a mess. The plumber who replaced it mentioned that he had replaced quite a few hot water heaters in our development for the same issue. He went to the Dennis Town Meeting to raise this issue and suggested that the Town needed to "sweeten the water".  The Town did but it hasn't really made much of a difference. This year we had a second hot water heater rot out. We were home when it happened, unlike the first time, and were able to shut off the water supply before we had a major mess. The source of this high acid level is oak leaves and pine needles falling on the ground but the Cape must deal with the acid coming from the fossil fuel power plants that increases acidification. BTW, I've done environmental planning.

Since we live in the Highlands of East Dennis, we have very few ponds but the nearest fresh water pond/lake is Scargo Lake.  Even though we don't use it for swimming or canoeing or kyacking, it is part of the amazing view of the Cape from the Scargo Tower, which is high on the hill overlooking the Lake and gives you a view from the hills of Plymouth, across the various necks out into the Bay, moving around to the arch of the Outer Cape Towns to the tip of Cape Cod.  At low tide you can even see the Pilgrim Memorial in Provincetown.  Many, many Cape Codders have never made the journey up there to enjoy the view but more should.

As even the Wampanoag people knew, since their name means 'People of the First Light', this coastal peninsula, we call Cape Cod, is a very special place, whether its the air, the water or the land. The Cape's topography is also special since it, like the Islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket and NY's Long Island, were all created by the glaciers of the past Ice Ages. That is why the northside of the Cape is much higher than the southside.  The leading edge of the glaciers pushed the sand, rock and boulders up and up and when they retreated the wind, the rains and the waters eroded the land to the south giving the Cape its wonderful Sound and Ocean beaches.  The remnants of the glaciers created the deep fresh water ponds and lakes from one end of the Cape to the other.  We do have to remember that the Cape we experience today is a third growth of trees.  The land of the Wampanoag was the first growth and these trees were cut for ship masts to be shipped back to the Old World.  The next growth of trees were cut for the building of the Cape.  By the time that Henry David Thoreau make his famous train, stage coach and walking trip the the Cape and wrote his book "Cape Cod", the Cape was virtually 'clear cut".  If we don't know about the Cape's past, how do we value its present and future.

Yes\nOver the past five or so years I have noticed that many of the culverts that connect salt marshes, creeks and smaller waterways to the Bay and Sound have been widened to increase the ability of tidal flow. A coordinated effort between all the towns is likely to be more affordable. More than that, it is more efficient. If Jason wants fast action, he is likely interested in a quick resolution. A coordinated effort between the towns means consistent waste water treatment policies across towns. What if Jason plans on expanding his cafe and opening another location in a different town. Does he want to learn a whole new set of waste water policies? Does he want to have to figure out how to adapt his operations to account for differing water standards? How much time will that cost him? How much money will that cost him? If towns are duplicating efforts, how much money are we spending to have different people do the same tasks in all the different towns? A coordinated and consistent waste water policy across all the towns in the region is a far more efficient use of taxpayer money (including Jason's) and leads to consistent policies that can be more easily administered across the region than each town trying to strike out on their own.

response: Here's my frustration...it's not a matter of my family being able to allocate $582/year. Almost any family can do that. I pay one of the highest real estate tax rates on the Cape and do not see my money being invested back into my community. Clearly, it's not being used for waste water. It's not being used for police and fire (we were just asked for a $30 million override). It's not being used for schools (one of our schools is being shut down because we can longer afford the maintenance). It's not being used for roads and sidewalks (just based on observation). I'm being asked to give more money to agencies that have already proven themselves to be utterly incapable of accomplishing tasks within a budget. How can I possibly have confidence that a) my $582/year will be allocated properly and b) the number won't magically balloon to something higher after we approve the spending? The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result.
replies: You should make a post about this on the Soapbox (https://communityplanit.org/capecod/public-square/soapbox/). It's an important conversation to have, IMO, and will likely go ignored buried here under other comments.\\ This is a good question...and valid in any public policy issue.  I hope the designers of the solution include solving the lack of transparency and general public/municipal bloat issue

In Betsy's situation, I would likely look to sell the property. Sentimental value does not offset financial burden. If Betsy truly wants to preserve the property for her kids and grandchildren then her best option is to become educated about the issue so she can take useful, concrete action.

Cape Cod is too small for ANY business owner not to be involved. Every decision made by our local government has an immediate and noticeable impact on the business environment. Yes, I've seen algae blooms. I've seen foam washed up along the shoreline of many ponds in the region.

I love to bike and hike around the area. It doesn't matter where you go, there's always something beautiful to see. Also, living in a small town means the chances are good that I'll run into a friend and neighbor while I'm out.

Inaction is not an option. But neither is slapping more financial burden on year round residents that are already stretched thin in a tough economy. It already feels like the federal, state, county and town governments have their hands firmly in my pocket and are leaving little left over. Priorities need to be set and town, county & state officials need to work together to determine what items are most important on every level. Budgets need to be set based on what's available instead of assuming that every town and county is entitled to every "important" override...if everything is important, then nothing is.

response: [[[41.76440942205953, -70.48540073013305]]]\nThe boardwalk in Sandwich is one of my favorite places.

My family summered on the Cape for generation. When I was 11, my parents finally made the jump and decided to move to the Cape. In the 22 years since, I have lived in Dennisport, Osterville and Sandwich. I have spent time with friends in Orleans, Harwich, Provincetown, Mashpee and Falmouth. I have been all over the Cape. This little slice of MA is beautiful but it presents unique challenges. How do we make it sustainable for people living here year round? How do we make it affordable for families and low wage earners that we need for the labor force and the tax base? What items make sense for towns to combine? When should towns hang onto their autonomy? How do maintain our quaint appeal while not falling too far behind technologically?
replies: these are great questions! exactly what we need to be deliberating about together, so we can make an informed and community-driven policy recommendations.

Yes\nI am all for "green" solutions. I recently saw a proposal for a stormwater garden that would transform an ugly storm drain into a beautiful above-ground garden with materials below ground that would filter groundwater. What a brilliant solution! It's something that could be created at businesses and homes all across the Cape, if not the state!

Direct growth to areas where treatment could be provided at a lower cost, Acquire and set aside open space to eliminate nitrogen from future growth, Use different wastewater treatment types for the newly developed areas\nGrowth is going to happen on Cape Cod. What's needed is a plan to help minimize potential harm caused by such growth. Open spaces and sewering are both important options. While sewering seems like an expensive and unnecessary option, it's not. We need a way for the wastewater we create to be filtered and processed properly to avoid further damage to our environment. It will be worth the cost in the long run.

How about a school project detailing the impact of nitrogen on water? Or perhaps adopting measures at home to help alleviate the problem, such as encouraging her parents to install some type of filtration system, stormwater gardens, or similar? Visuals are especially powerful, which is why I suggest the school project - poster, PowerPoint. Through such a method, Mia should remind her parents that she wants a Cape Cod in her future, too.

Dear Frank: If you choose to vote "yes" you will be doing the Cape Community a tremendous service. By preserving our environment and it's varied ecosystems you will also be supporting the longevity of the Cape, and ultimately its schools by giving our children a place of unparalleled value that will prove its worth in years to come. Without a strong environment the Cape's economy will suffer greatly, and not just its schools. With environmental degradation will come a loss of tourism, which will impact local businesses severely. Local businesses will ultimately close, leaving people without places to shop, eat, visit, etc. People will have no choice but to move off-Cape, which means no children to fill the schools. As another member said, the environment IS our economy.

It would be devastating. I'm already paying rent I feel is far too high for where I live, and to have that rent raised to cover revenue decreases would probably force me to move off-Cape. While that seems insignificant since I'm just one person, there would be economic fallout. I am year-round, dine out frequently, shop local merchants, work at a local business, and take advantage of local amenities. I'm surely not the only financially challenged person on the Cape, and yet we all impact the economy. Imagine if more of us had to leave?

[[[41.78999640994269, -69.99065118408203]]]\nI believe it's the Orleans/Eastham/Wellfleet area because of all the water. Orleans is especially attractive because it's got beaches galore, as well as freshwater ponds, and it's still close to the highway.

Cape Cod is one of the most magical places on Earth. Not only does it have miles of incredible beaches boasting numerous types of sea creatures, but walking trails that traverse acres of tranquil woodlands, and bicycle paths that allow riders to travel along the canal, or past stunning vistas, ponds, lakes and cranberry bogs. But it is the simple things that also come to mind: That first wondrous flash of yellow, coupled with an unmistakable song that heralds the return of brightly plumed Orioles in springtime; the crack of baseballs against wooden bats at Cape League games in the summer; the sound of gentle rain on a porch roof; a dusting of snow along a pathway or sandy beach; the way each village glows amidst holiday decor each year...The Cape is rich with history that encompasses much, including our very own indigenous people, the Wampanoag. In its 400+ years of existence, I have no doubt that the tribe has experienced great impacts to its ways of living, particularly involving their practices of gaining sustenance from land and sea creatures. There aren't as many fish or shellfish anymore and the Cape's ever-increasing population makes it difficult to hunt effectively.If we don't work together to solve the Cape's environmental problems, the history becomes meaningless because if we don't take care of our Cape, there won't be a Cape to take care of.

I have seen erosion in so many places. I feel as if I've been seeing an increase in seaweed in recent years, and I know I've seen an uptick in the amount of trash on the beaches. The water in some places (Kalmus, Sea Street in Dennis, Smuggler's in Yarmouth) seems less clear than I remember it being a few years ago.

In Yarmouth there is the Seaside Festival, and during the summer local businesses become sites for professionally sculpted sandcastles, evoking the beach. In the Town of Barnstable there are a number of annual festivals, some pertaining directly to water, some that simply happen in the different villages. One that comes to mind immediately that is a Cape-wide event is the annual Lifeguard Competition, which takes place on the Cape's many beaches (Craigville, Nauset, West Dennis). In terms of produce-based events, there are any number of scallop festivals, as well as the annual Chowderfest at the Melody Tent, not to mention the impressive number of farmer's markets that feature locally grown produce and seafoods. Doesn't get much fresher than scallops harvested that morning for sale that afternoon.

Barnstable, Chatham, Dennis, Orleans, Provincetown, Sandwich, Yarmouth\nEvery year on no particular date (typically late summer) I hop in my car and drive as much of the Cape as I can before the sun goes down. I always bring my camera and make it a point to snap as many photos as possible. It is my hope that in time I will come to know as many of the Cape's roads as possible, and therefore as many of its marvelous places. This is a magical area and we should pay it more respect.

For me, the first thing I think of when I think of Cape Cod is water. Everywhere you go there is a beautiful body of water to gaze upon, swim in, boat upon, walk along the shoreline of, you name it. I find the Cape's waters soothing and invigorating. When I am in need of a recharge I visit a beach. I listen to and watch the waves crash. If it's warm enough, I swim. If I'm lucky to have time, I snorkel, delighting in all the undersea treasures I find, from fish to seashells and more. It is the waters that make the Cape so special.
Stunning.

response: If nothing changes, if rental companies continue using outdated systems and home and business owners continue using systems that flood area waters with nitrogen, Lin won't have much to enjoy in the way of beautiful waters. They'll be too choked with algae. If that happens, the wildlife will die off, impacting on-land wildlife that feeds on whatever is in the water. When those creatures are impacted others will be, as well, right up the food chain to humans. Visually, our scenic areas will become much less scenic and possibly become so toxic no one will be able to swim or boat in the waters. That will impact tourism greatly, resulting in fewer visitors and a serious dent into our economy. Ignoring the problem won't make it go away. It will only make it worse.

My watershed contributes to a coastal bay (embayment)\nI reside in an embayment and am a renter. I am deeply concerned about where I live since the rental company overseeing the property still uses maximum flush toilets (rather than the 1.5 gallon), and irrigates the lawns after infusing them with some kind of chemical. I know when they've put down the chemical/fertilizer/spray because a little sign gets put in the grass warning us to stay off it for 48 hours. If people and pets can't walk on whatever they're using, how can it be good for the environment?!

For this challenge I really wanted to venture into/onto the waters around where I live and really look for algae. Unfortunately time is of the essence and I am unable. However, just this morning I saw a news piece about algae in Brewster. I've seen and heard of algae in Cotuit, Centerville, Barnstable, and Yarmouth (Dennis Pond). Having conducted water testing with my father in NH, I know how precious the Cape's water bodies are. I long to help.

One of my favorite outdoor activities is stand-up paddleboarding, followed closely by riding my bike on the side streets and trails around the Cape. I'm planning a day along the canal this fall. SUP brings me out on the water (when I'm able to go), while biking lets me explore different areas of the Cape from a two-wheeled vantage point. One of my favorite trips was on the trail from Dennis to Orleans. It was a long ride but the sights and the experience were amazing!

I grew up spending my summers swimming in a lake in NH. My father was a staunch protector of that lake, on which he now lives. I learned from and have been inspired by his passion for protecting a vital aspect of our lives. If I do nothing, the waters I cherish so deeply around Cape Cod will become choked with algae and will cease being safe for swimming, fishing, shellfishing, and more. I envision visiting a favorite body of water in sadness as I realize there are few, if any, fish or other creatures living beneath because of the nitrogen. I would feel a sense of sorrow that a problem we have the power to solve got so out of hand.

There is something to marvel at every day, no matter the weather or season, and I'm not just talking about the scenery. There are theaters galore, restaurants to suit all palates, museums, and, of course, beaches. I love the Cape.

Yes\nThe more holistic and long-sighted an approach invested in now, the better. Rather than tackle this environmental issue (which is also always an economic issue, too) in a piece-meal, stop-gap solution manner, it will be more effective (and financially sound) to lay out some funds now for a many-pronged approach. Conserving natural space has multiple benefits for the Cape's environment, even as it impinges directly on the problem at hand of eutrophication.

Direct growth to areas where treatment could be provided at a lower cost, Acquire and set aside open space to eliminate nitrogen from future growth, Use different wastewater treatment types for the newly developed areas\nWaste water management implies foresighted land management when it comes to future growth and development on the Cape.

She can start raising the issue in conversations around the dinner table. She can opt to give a portion of her income from babysitting or allowance to organizations that are advocating for Cape-wide solutions to the problem of waste water and eutrophication. She can start a student organization at her school that other students interested in the environment can get involved in and amplify each others voices in the community.  There are any number of ways she can get involved now.

What if certain additional revenues collected were earmarked specifically for addressing the issue of waste water management? It seems imperative schools should be adequately funded to meet the needs of the families who use them, but in order to keep future generations on the Cape (some of whom may have been educated there), it will be necessary to preserve the environment to make it a healthy and desirable place to live.

My knee-jerk reaction is that this would have a deleterious effect on household finances, but I wonder, overall, if there might be a "freakonomics" to this quandary. While property values along the coast plummeting seems almost inconceivable, might there not be an opening up of opportunity for people to insert themselves in once-out-of-reach places to find ways to heal and benefit from the new situation? If we are to make sense of this problem in the here-and-now, I think we have to consider the long-range issue of the environment and eco-diversity, rather than locating the heart of this issue in short-term personal finances, even though the latter is often the motivating force behind people's (in)action - not just on the Cape, but everywhere.

Because I don't live on the Cape, I rely on the collective wisdom and foresight of the residents to make good decisions about regional infrastructure. I understand the need for and hands-on quality that distinct local governments bring to the flavor of each town, but something like waste water affects the whole region and without a unified movement across the Cape, keeping things status quo could make it unpleasant to visit - much less live on there year-round.

I can't imagine a world where the Cape is not a big part of who I am.

After two generations of declining water quality, Chatham has tackled the problem with a centralized sewer collection and treatment plan.  Previous appearances of scum in Mill Pond, Oyster Pond and Stage Harbor will hopefully become rare in the future.Oyster Pond may be opened to shellfishing year-round in the next year or two, after 20+ years of seasonal closures.  Unfortunately the one shellfish grant-holder had to close operations for two weeks recently.  Reasons unknown.  May have been a combination of high temperatures, seagulls perched on cages and/or illegal boat discharges.  Hopefully not to be repeated.Most Chatham residents, including Selectmen, are supportive of Chatham's approach, including the higher taxes required.  We all recognize that clean waters are critical to our fishermen, shell fishermen, residents and tourists. We decided not to wait in hopes of alternatives which might or might not workChatham has been diligent in obtaining state and federal grants, and will be splitting the remaining costs between taxpayers and water/sewer users over the next 20-30 years.

Fifty years from now I would love to see Cape waters with healthy levels of nutrients, plants, and animals. I hope the Cape will be a place where people and animals coexist and where water and land resources are sufficient to support everyone.Pictured is a young male harbor seal rehabilitated at National Marine Life Center and released today. Among other conditions, he was suffering from an ear infection. Did that ear infection come from something unhealthy in the ocean? Can people also be impacted by an unhealthy ocean? It is important to remember that environmental health, wildlife health, and human health are all interconnected. The Cape Cod Commission should involve people through creativity - such as this game - providing multiple channels for people to get involved with and invested in solution building. Through flexibility - working with communities to develop solutions tailored to local conditions that also contribute to a regional approach. And through effective communication and education programs and multiple channels for people to get involved and invested in solution building. "In the end, we conserve only what we love. We will love only what we understand. We will understand only what we are taught."     ~ Baba Dioum, Senegalese Environmentalist

Might Open Cape provide opportunities for creative ways to involve nontraditional participants in the decision making process?

My local pond is Queen Sewell Pond, also locally known as Bump's Pond in Buzzards Bay. I most often enjoy it by walking my dog near by. Sometimes we go down the boat ramp and look for turtles and fish. When (if) it freezes in the winter, it's fun to walk on. People in the neighborhood use the pond for swimming, sitting, fishing, wading, boating (small boats). It's a nice resource for our community.

For me, a lot of the unique aspects of Cape Cod have to do with marine animals, and in particular marine animal strandings. We have more dolphin mass strandings here on Cape Cod than anywhere else in the country. And the third highest rate in the world. We have more cold stunned sea turtle strandings than anywhere in the country outside the Southeastern U.S. (FL, Gulf). These strandings present a tremendous opportunity and responsibility - both to help and to learn more about why they occur.

Yes\nGreen solutions such as wetlands, open space, and improving tidal function are important elements of a regional wastewater treatment plan. They would add to the beauty of Cape Cod, add important wildlife habitat, and add valuable recreation space. A potential reduction of cost versus traditional wastewater treatment is an added bonus!

Change current development rules to limit growth, Direct growth to areas where treatment could be provided at a lower cost, Acquire and set aside open space to eliminate nitrogen from future growth, Something else, Use different wastewater treatment types for the newly developed areas\nI especially like directing growth to areas where treatment could be provided at a lower cost. There are a number of areas around the Cape that could benefit from redevelopment and infilling of underutilized or degraded properties. Also, how about encouraging more multi family units such as apartments. This could go a long way towards also addressing affordable housing on the Cape.

Mia can do a lot by educating her parents about the problem and why it's important from her point of view. She could talk to them about how important it is to her that the Cape she grows up to enjoy is as healthy as the one they grew up enjoying. She could encourage them to take immediate steps of reducing or eliminating lawn fertilizer and she could set an example by reducing her own water use. She could focus on the problem in her school projects and reports, and share these with her parents. If she shows her parents how important this issue is, they will want to get involved - for her sake!Here's a great essay that a 13 year old in New York wrote about a dying lake and eutrophication. She won a Young Naturalist Award from the American Museum of Natural History.http://www.amnh.org/learn-teach/young-naturalist-awards/winning-essays2/2003-winning-essays/oscawana-a-dying-lake

People will move away resulting in a lower tax base. Businesses will close also resulting in a lower tax base. It will be a downward spiral that will severely impact schools.
It depends on the tax rate. If it continued to increase as property values decreased, I would eventually not be able to make ends meet.

Protecting the environment is good for our local economy. Clean water and healthy ecosystems attract residents, visitors, business. Unhealthy ecosystems lower the quality of life and ultimately discourage growth and development. In the long run, it costs more money to clean up the environment after the fact rather than protecting it for the future.

Since I answered the questions in the earlier challenge, I've learned that my local pond - Queen Sewell Pond aka Bumps Pond in Buzzards Bay - has been closed to swimming due to an algae bloom. It really hit close to home! A change that has really struck me this year is the scouring of the dunes at Boardwalk Beach after last winter's storms. Over the years and with the passing of the seasons I've seen subtle changes, but this year was dramatic. I will be interested to see what happens next.

The biggest festival in Bourne is the Scallop Festival. It is connected to the water both by celebrating a water based food item and by it's location next to the Cape Cod Canal. Over 40,000 people from all over New England visit the Festival, which is great for our town. Another festival is our annual Fourth of July Parade. It's fun to see the whole community come out to celebrate and cheer on the home made floats!

response: My community, Bourne, has several very nice fresh water and salt water beaches. However, the water feature most iconic of our town is the Cape Cod Canal. The Canal is a wonderful place, one of recreation, transportation, commerce, learning, wildlife, community, motion, contemplation. At the same time, it presents a physical and emotional barrier isolating part of the town from the rest of the Cape Cod community. It is these many qualities of the Canal that shape the identity of Bourne.
Bridge. Not only the obvious (although the Bourne and Sagamore and Railroad are here), but also the metaphorical bridge between the mainland and the Cape.

Composting food and waste, Using nitrogen-free household products, Reducing or eliminating the use of fertilizers on your yard, Installing special landscaping that captures stormwater runoff, Installing special bathroom fixtures, Something else (explain in your comment)\nI'm pleased to learn I'm already taking many of the recommended measures! Now I will look even more carefully at my products and practices to see what else I can do.

In the past 2 years\nOwning a house with a septic system was a bit intimidating as I had never used one before. It is important to inform oneself on proper maintenance and have it pumped regularly. When it comes time to replace mine, I hope there are cost effective solutions to eliminate nitrogen. In the meantime, I wonder if someone might invent a product or additive that could reduce nitrogen on existing systems. hmmm....

First, I would eliminate using nitrogen-based fertilizers and look at organic lawn care. I would also change out my toilet(s) for low-flow versions, install water saving fixtures on all sinks, and invest in a water saving washing machine. Then I would start saving for a new septic system and research options to finance it. Are there low-interest loans available? Betterment funds? Might there be a solution that could be shared with other neighbors? And, I'd take steps to become more informed and active about the issue.

Addressing the waste water issue is critical to every business owner and resident on Cape Cod. Although it may not seem like it, Jason's business and family will be directly impacted if the issue is not addressed. Jason's business depends on people coming in to the Cafe, buying his cookies, and spending money. If the waste water issue is not addressed, the elements that make the Cape so attractive - our natural habitat - will decline. People will not want to come here to visit or live, companies will not want to move here because the infrastructure does not support him, and the whole economy will decline. For Jason, this means less business. He definitely won't be able to open his new franchises and may wind up closing the stores he already has open. And, this will impact his ability to support his family. It is critical to get involved in decision making! Even if going to public meetings aren't his "thing", he could take steps to address the problem. He could implement sustainable practices in his businesses and at home. He could support those working on the problem. He could post educational information in his businesses. He can be part of the solution!

If nothing is done about the nitrogen problem, the Cape will become a less attractive place to live and work. This will result in fewer visitors, less business development, and an economic decline. There will be fewer jobs available for Lin or her parents. However, it's not to late to get involved and help preserve Cape Cod's future. Lin and her parents could play this game! and become more knowledgeable about the issues. They could get involved with regional policy planning. They could take steps at home to reduce nitrogen by limiting use of lawn fertilizers and investing in an upgraded septic system that removes nitrogen. If they live in a town where it makes sense economically, they could support local sewerage efforts. They could vote for policy makers whose platforms include responsible waste water management.  They could donate to and volunteer with organizations working to address the problem.
My watershed drains to the open ocean\nI live in Buzzards Bay where, as I just learned, water in my watershed drains directly into the ocean.

I haven't seen many algae blooms on Cape Cod. The Canal, where I spend most time, has a strong water flow and there is very little algae. Boardwalk Beach, where I walk my dog, so far has been pretty clean. However, algae blooms can be very damaging. Not only with eutrophication but some algae can bloom in toxic form and cause fish kills, marine mammal stranding events, and even harm people. For so many reasons, we need to address excess nitrogen around the Cape!http://oceanservice.noaa.gov/hazards/hab/
I love watching the abundance of wildlife we have here. Whale watching, seal watching, bird watching, beach combing - the Cape is a wonderful place to enjoy nature!

Taking action to reduce nitrogen pollution in the Cape Cod ecosystem is critical to our growth and prosperity as a region. This will mean some tough decisions, but it will only get tougher if we wait.
